revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Abuja Stock Exchange''' (ASE) was set up in 2000 and went live in 2001. It was the first [[stock exchange|exchange]] in [[Nigeria]] to provide [[electronic trading]], clearing and Settlement for both the [[primary market]] as well as [[secondary market]]s. It was set up to trade in equities, unlisted stocks and plain vanilla bonds.
Soon after its launch a government notification forced it to close its operations. This was orchestrated by the more powerful [[Nigerian Stock Exchange]] which lobbied with the government to maintain its monopoly over the Nigerian stock markets. The reasoning for the notification was that there was no need for a second stock exchange in the country.
However, efforts are currently on to convert the existing infrastructure into a multicommodity exchange [[commodities exchange]].
==See also== *[[Stock exchange]]
[[Category:Stock exchanges in Nigeria]] [[Category:Economy of Nigeria]] [[Category:Companies of Nigeria]]
{{Nigeria-stub}} {{Stockexchange-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = Alexion Pharmaceuticals, Inc. | logo = Alexion Pharmaceuticals logo.svg | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{unbulleted list|{{NASDAQ|ALXN}}|[[NASDAQ-100]] component|[[S&P 500]] component}} | founded = 1992 | founder = Leonard Bell | key_people = Leonard Bell ([[Chairman]])
[[Ludwig N. Hantson]] ([[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]]) | industry = [[Pharmaceutical industry|Pharmaceutical]] | products = [[Eculizumab|Soliris]] | revenue = {{nowrap|{{increase}} [[United States dollar|US$]]3,551.1 million {{small|(2017)}}}} | operating_income = {{nowrap|{{decrease}} US$627.4 million {{small|(2017)}}}} | net_income = {{nowrap|{{increase}} US$443.3 million {{small|(2017)}}}} | assets = {{nowrap|{{increase}} US$13,583.3 million {{small|(2017)}}}} | equity = {{nowrap|{{increase}} US$8,893.1 million {{small|(2017)}}}} | num_employees = {{decrease}} 2,794 | num_employees_year = {{small|2017}} | location_city = [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S. | website = {{URL|www.alxn.com}} | footnotes = {{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/899866/000089986618000022/alxn10k12312017.htm |title=Alexion Pharmaceuticals 2017 Annual Report Form (10-K) |publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] |date=February 8, 2018 |accessdate=August 26, 2018}} }} '''Alexion Pharmaceuticals Inc.''' is an American pharmaceutical company best known for its development of [[Eculizumab|Soliris]], a drug used to treat the rare disorders [[atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome]] (aHUS) and [[paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria]] (PNH).{{cite web|url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/221849.php|title=Alexion Submits Application for Soliris|date=2011-04-08}}{{cite web |url= https://www.forbes.com/companies/alexion-pharmaceuticals/ |title=Alexion Pharmaceuticals on the Forbes World’s Most Innovative Companies List|work=forbes.com|accessdate=28 September 2012}} The company is also involved in immune system research related to autoimmune diseases. It employs 2,794 people worldwide.{{cite web |url=https://numhub.co/stats/28402-alexion-pharmaceuticals-inc/28715-number-of-employees |title=Alexion Pharmaceuticals, Inc. number of employees |work=numhub.co |accessdate=2 December 2018}} In February 2016, the company held the dedication ceremony for its new headquarters in New Haven, Connecticut, not far from the company's starting point in the same city.{{cite web|url=http://photos.newhavenregister.com/2016/02/29/photos-of-alexion-pharmaceuticals-global-hq-dedication/#1|title=Photos of Alexion Pharmaceuticals World HQ Dedication|publisher=}} In September 2017, Alexion announced it would be moving its headquarters to [[Boston, Massachusetts]] in mid-2018.{{cite news |last=Singer |first=Stephen |url=http://www.courant.com/news/connecticut/hc-alexion-moving-new-haven-boston-20170911-story.html |title=Alexion Exits New Haven For Boston, Agrees To Repay Millions In State Aid |work=[[Hartford Courant]] |date=2017-09-12 |accessdate=2017-09-12 }} ==History== Alexion Pharmaceuticals was founded in 1992 at [[Science Park]] in [[New Haven, Connecticut]] by Steven Squinto and Leonard Bell. {{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewherper/2012/09/05/how-a-440000-drug-is-turning-alexion-into-biotechs-new-innovation-powerhouse/#d3819ca25e11|title=How A $440,000 Drug Is Turning Alexion Into Biotech's New Innovation Powerhouse|last=Herper|first=Matthew|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en}} Bell served as the company's CEO until 2015. In 2000, Alexion moved its headquarters from New Haven to [[Cheshire, Connecticut]]. Alexion moved back to New Haven following the completion of New Haven's Downtown Crossing project in December 2015. Since 2006, Alexion has been a supporter of healthcare research and quality studies at [[Duke University]] for aspirin and [[Clopidogrel]] (trade name '''Plavix''').{{cite web|url=http://www.medpagetoday.com/Cardiology/PCI/4638 |title= More Support for Long-Term Plavix to Improve Stent Safety |date=Dec 5, 2006 |accessdate=Jul 18, 2013}} Alexion received U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) approval for Soliris in 2007. It was initially approved to treat [[paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria]], a rare blood disorder.{{cite news|title=Everything you need to know about the $8.4B acquisition of Synageva|author=Don Seiffert|work=Boston Business Journal|date=May 6, 2015|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/bioflash/2015/05/everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-8-4b.html|accessdate=May 8, 2015}} In 2010, there was an outbreak of [[hemolytic-uremic syndrome]] caused by [[Verotoxin-producing Escherichia coli|Enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli]] (EHEC) in Germany. Soliris was considered a treatment option because of its effectiveness in treating [[Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome]], an illness similar to the one caused by the EHEC infection.{{cite web|url=http://www.hartfordbusiness.com/news18747.html|title=Alexion treating Europe's E coli victims|date=2011-05-31}} In April 2011, Alexion was added to the [[NASDAQ-100]], a group composed of the 100 largest non-financial stocks traded on the [[NASDAQ]]; with a market value of USD 8.5 billion it replaced [[Genzyme|Genzyme Corporation]].{{cite web|url=http://ir.nasdaqomx.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=560664|title=Alexion Pharmaceuticals, Inc. to Join the NASDAQ-100 Index Beginning April 4, 2011|date=2011-03-29}} In April 2015, Bell was replaced as CEO by David Hallal. In 2016, the company became a member of the [[Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America]] (PhRMA).{{cite web|url=http://www.fiercepharma.com/pharma/teva-wins-controversial-phrma-bid-despite-protests-from-branded-rivals|title=Teva wins controversial PhRMA bid despite protests from branded rivals - FiercePharma }} In December 2016, Alexion's board of directors announced new leadership. David Brennan, a current board member, became interim CEO. David Anderson, formerly the CFO of [[Honeywell]], was appointed CFO, replacing Vikas Sinha.{{Cite press release |url=http://news.alexionpharma.com/press-release/company-news/alexions-board-directors-announces-new-leadership-appointments|title=Alexion’s Board of Directors Announces New Leadership Appointments {{!}} Alexion Pharmaceuticals, Inc|website=news.alexionpharma.com|access-date=2016-12-12}} In March 2017, Alexion named [[Ludwig N. Hantson]] as its new CEO.{{cite news|last=Grover |first=Natalie |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-alexion-pharms-moves-ceo-idUSKBN16Y157 |title=Alexion Pharma names former Baxalta chief Ludwig Hantson CEO |agency=Reuters |date=March 27, 2017 |accessdate=March 27, 2017}} In September 2017, Alexion announced that it would be closing its Smithfield, RI manufacturing facility. ===Acquisitions=== In 2000, Alexion purchased Proliferon Inc., a [[San Diego, California]]-based development-stage biopharmaceutical firm, for US$41 million in Alexion stock. Alexion CEO, Leonard Bell, cited Proliferon's ability to produce an "unlimited amount of antibodies" as the reason for the acquisition. At the time Proliferon's annual revenue was about $2.5 million and its assets were valued at $2.1 million.{{cite web|url=http://ir.alexionpharm.com/secfiling.cfm?filingID=1005477-00-8099|title=Alexion Buys Calif. Firm;Proliferon acquired in $41 million deal|date=2000-02-10}}{{cite web|url=http://ir.alexionpharm.com/secfiling.cfm?filingID=1005477-00-8099|title=Securities and Exchange Commission Alexion 8-K 2000 Report|date=2000-09-18}} The company has since been renamed Alexion Antibody Technologies Inc. In December 2011, Alexion acquired Montreal-based Enobia Pharma Corp, the developer of asfotase alpha, a drug used to treat the genetic disorder [[hypophosphatasia]].{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-29/alexion-to-pay-as-much-as-1-08-billion-to-buy-enobia-pharma.html|title=Alexion to Pay as Much as $1.08 Billion to Buy Enobia Pharma|date=December 29, 2011 |newspaper=Business Week}} In May 2015, Alexion announced plans to purchase the Lexington firm [[Synageva BioPharma]], a maker of rare disease treatments, in a $8.4 billion stock-and-cash deal.{{cite news |title=How Genzyme became a source of biotech executives |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2015/07/11/genzyme-family-tree-how-henri-termeer-spawned-network-genzyme-alums-leading-dozens-biotechs-from-cambridge-stockholm/Dkoz2zcLlNz3N6OZbOvN4L/story.html# |newspaper=The Boston Globe |date=12 July 2015 |accessdate=17 July 2015 |author=Robert Weisman}} The price represented more than a 135% premium over Synageva's market cap at the time. It also represented a valuation of about ten times projected peak sales, double what is typical for the biotech industry.{{cite news|title=Alexion Puts Its Soaring Stock Price to Good Use|date=May 6, 2015|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/07/business/dealbook/alexion-puts-its-soaring-stock-price-to-good-use.html|accessdate=May 7, 2015|work=The New York Times|author=Robert Cyran}} In April 2018, Alexion announced the acquisition of [[Wilson Therapeutics]] for $855 million.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-wilson-therapeut-m-a-alexion-pharms/biotech-ma-rolls-on-as-alexion-snaps-up-wilson-for-855-million-idUSKBN1HI236|title=Biotech M&A rolls on as Alexion snaps up Wilson for $855 million|last=Hirschler|first=Ben|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-04-11|language=en-US}}{{cite web|url=https://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/alexion-to-acquire-wilson-therapeutics-for-855m/81255689|title=Alexion to Acquire Wilson Therapeutics for $855M - GEN|author=|date=|website=GEN}} In September the company announced it was to acquire [[Syntimmune]] for $1.2 billion - expanding its rare disease offering.https://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/alexion-to-acquire-syntimmune-for-up-to-12b-expanding-rare-disease-pipeline/81256274https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-syntimmune-m-a-alexion-pharms/alexion-to-buy-biotech-firm-syntimmune-for-up-to-1-2-billion-idUKKCN1M61DU ===Acquisition history=== The following is an illustration of the company's mergers, acquisitions, [[Corporate spin-off|spin-offs]] and historical predecessors: {{clade | style=font-size:90%;line-height:110% |thickness=0 |label1='''Alexion Pharmaceuticals''' |1={{clade |label1= |1={{clade |label1= |1={{clade |label1= |1={{clade |label1= |1={{clade |label1= |1={{clade |label1= |1={{clade |1={{clade |1=Alexion Pharmaceuticals
(Founded 1992) }}}} |label2= |2={{clade |1=Proliferon Inc
(Acq 2000, restructured into Alexion Antibody Technologies Inc) }}}} |label2= |2= {{clade |1=Enobia Pharma Corp
(Acq 2011) }}}} |label2= |2={{clade |1=[[Synageva BioPharma]]
(Acq 2015) }}}} |label2= |2={{clade |1=[[Wilson Therapeutics]]
(Acq 2018) }}}} |label2= |2={{clade |1=[[Syntimmune]]
(Acq 2018) }}}}}}}} == Ownership == As of 2017 Alexion Pharmaceuticals shares are mainly held by institutional investors ([[Fidelity Investments]], [[T. Rowe Price]], [[BlackRock]] and others{{cite web|url=http://www.nasdaq.com/symbol/alxn/ownership-summary|title=Alexion Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (ALXN) Ownership Summary|author=|date=|website=NASDAQ.com}}) ==Products== ===Specialty drugs=== {{main|Specialty drugs}} Alexion has employed a strategy of developing drugs to combat rare diseases. Since the targeted user base is small for such drugs, clinical drugs tend to be quicker{{vague|Quicker in what way? Quicker to research? Clinical trials? Quicker to develop? To market?|date=June 2018}} and cheaper than those for mass market drugs. Additionally, big pharmaceutical companies have tended to ignore these markets, creating a niche with minimal competition for Alexion. Insurance companies have generally been willing to pay high prices for such drugs; since few of their customers need the drugs, a high price does not significantly impact the insurance companies' outlays. "The success of specialty drugs for rare diseases comes at a time when the traditional drug business of selling medicines to the masses is in decline...Specialty drugs have gotten more expensive than anyone imagined." ====Soliris==== {{main|Eculizumab}} Alexion's first drug, Soliris, first launched in 2007, used to treat the rare disorders [[atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome]] (aHUS) and [[Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria]] (PNH). It has been approved for use in Canada, the European Union, Japan, and the United States; however, availability in Canada is limited. In Canada, access to the drug is mostly through private clinics; groups such as the Canadian Association of PNH Patients are lobbying to change that.{{cite web|url=http://www.zacks.com/stock/news/50969/Alexion+Seeks+Label+Expansion|title=Alexion Seeks Label Expansion|date=2011-04-08}} The drug costs roughly $450,000 a year, and is considered the world's most expensive drug. The price of the drug is so high that very few individuals can pay the price. As a result, Alexion hires public relations firms to help families institute campaigns to pressure their governments to pay for the drug. Alexion is putting pressure on to governments to receive their payments from the public purse. The prices charged have a very high margin above the cost price. In addition, much of the research for the development of Soliris originates from publicly funded universities. There is an ethical question as to the pricing of the drug and the ethics of the drug manufacturer. Alexion is well on the way to developing a second very high price and high margined drug.{{citation |title=A Price to Pay: how the manufacturer pulls on emotions - patients, families, politicians and governments around the world |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/health/how-pharmaceutical-company-alexion-set-the-price-of-the-world-s-most-expensive-drug-1.3125251 |author=Kelly Crowe, |publisher=CBC News |date=25 June 2015 |accessdate=18 July 2015}} In September 2011, the FDA officially approved the use of Soliris as a treatment for [[Hemolytic-uremic syndrome#Atypical cases|atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome]] in both adults and children. More than half of people with aHUS end up dying of it as a result of damage to vital organs/organ failure (usually involving the kidneys) caused by uncontrolled complement activation. The FDA's decision to grant approval received a positive response from the medical community with the director of Pediatric Nephrology at Atlanta's Children's hospital calling it "the most important advance that has been made for patients and families with this disease".{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110923005612/en/Soliris%C2%AE-eculizumab-Approved-FDA-Patients-Atypical-Hemolytic|title=Soliris® (eculizumab) Approved by FDA for All Patients with Atypical Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (aHUS)|date=September 23, 2011}} By 2010 Soliris was considered to be the most expensive drug in the world.{{citation |title=The World's Most Expensive Drugs |url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/02/19/expensive-drugs-cost-business-healthcare-rare-diseases.html |date=February 19, 2010 |accessdate=June 25, 2015 |first=Matthew |last=Herper |work=Forbes}} It costs £340,200 per year for treatment in the UK{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/doctors-must-tell-patients-of-errors-under-new-law-from-varadkar-1.2092525|title=Doctors must tell patients of errors, under new Varadkar law|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nice.org.uk/news/press-and-media/high-cost-of-treatment-for-rare-blood-disorder-needs-to-be-clarified-says-nice-in-draft-guidance|title=High cost of treatment for rare blood disorder needs to be clarified, says NICE in draft guidance|author=|date=|website=nice.org.uk}} and $500,000 a year in Canada. and US$409,500 a year in the United States (2010). In the case of the rarest diseases that afflict fewer than 10,000 people, biotech companies who own the only approved drugs to treat those diseases "can charge pretty much whatever they want." "Before testing Soliris for PNH, Alexion tested the drug for [[rheumatoid arthritis]], which afflicts 1 million Americans. The trials failed. But if it had worked for arthritis, Alexion would likely have had to charge a much lower price for this use, as it would have to compete against drugs that cost a mere $20,000." Alexion started selling Soliris in 2008 making $295 million in 2007 with its stock price rising to 130% in 2010.{{citation |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2014/12/04/toronto_woman_with_rare_disease_fights_province_for_lifesaving_but_costly_drug.html |title=Toronto woman with rare disease fights province for life-saving but costly drug Soliris, which costs $500,000 a year, would treat Toni Vernon's blood disease, but the health ministry is holding back |first=Jacques |last=Gallant|date=December 4, 2014 |accessdate=June 25, 2015}} In April and May 2013, a controversy arose in Belgium when the media revealed that the government had refused to pay for a seven-year-old boy's treatment because Soliris was too expensive. The boy's medicine cost 9,000 euros every two weeks.{{cite web|url=http://deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws/binnenland/1.1617223|title=Viktor (7) moet elke twee weken infuus krijgen van 9.000 euro|date=April 30, 2013}} On May 4, 2013, ''[[De Standaard]]'' reported that a press relations (PR) agency working for Alexion had helped the boy's parents communicate their story to the press.{{cite web|url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/DMF20130504_00566977|title=Pr-bureau van farmabedrijf adviseerde ook ouders Viktor|date=May 4, 2013}} It was also reported that the parents had believed their benefactor was a Dutch organization for patients, and that the PR agency acted with permission from Alexion.{{cite web|url=http://deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws/binnenland/130504_Alexion_Viktor|title=Farmabedrijf Alexion heeft Viktor "gebruikt"|date=May 4, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/DMF20130506_00568721|title=Farmabaas fluit Alexion terug in zaak-Viktor|date=May 6, 2013}} Several politicians stated that the company was attempting to 'blackmail' the government, charges which Alexion denied.{{cite web|url=http://deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws/binnenland/1.1619457 |title=Detiège: "Dit is chantage van het farmabedrijf"|date=May 2, 2013}} By May 7, 2013 an agreement had been reached to reimburse the medicine.{{cite web|url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/DMF20130507_00570744|title=Medicijn Viktor vanaf juli terugbetaald|date=May 7, 2013}} Pharma, the Belgian pharmaceutical industry's association, opened an internal investigation into the affair, for possible breach of the association's ethical standards by Alexion. However, on June 12, Alexion received a court [[gag order]] against Pharma, preventing it from communicating its investigation. At the same time, Pharma opened a court case against Alexion Pharma Belgium. The gag order was revoked by the end of September 2013,{{cite web |url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/dmf20131001_00768977 |title= Spreekverbod Pharma.be opgeheven|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher= |accessdate=2015-03-24 }} but the case was still pending in March 2015.{{cite web |url= http://www.demorgen.be/binnenland/-contract-van-onkelinx-met-farmareus-opent-doos-van-pandora-a2261432/ |title= Contract van Onkelinx met farmareus opent doos van Pandora |date= 2015-03-23|accessdate=2015-03-24}} In October 2017 the FDA approved the use of Soliris to treat adult patients with generalized [[myasthenia gravis]] (gMG).{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestreet.com/story/14356628/1/alexion-pharmaceuticals-stock-jumps-on-fda-approval-of.html|title=Alexion Pharmaceuticals Stock Jumps on FDA Approval of Soliris|last=Bruno|first=Giovanni|date=2017-10-24|work=TheStreet|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}} In November 2017 the company received a patent for Soliris from the [[Japan Patent Office|Japanese Patent Office]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.streetinsider.com/Corporate+News/Alexion+Pharma+(ALXN)+Receives+New+Japanese+Patent+for+Soliris/13466411.html|title=Alexion Pharma (ALXN) Receives New Japanese Patent for Soliris|work=StreetInsider.com|access-date=2017-11-07}} ====Strensiq==== In October 2015, Alexion's second drug, Strensiq ([[asfotase alfa]]), was approved by the US FDA. It is used to treat [[hypophosphatasia]], a rare metabolic disorder. ====Kanuma==== [[Kanuma (drug)|Kanuma]], which Alexion acquired in its acquisition of Synageva, was approved in 2015 to treat [[lysosomal acid lipase deficiency]], a fatal genetic disorder that cause fatty material to build up in blood vessel walls, the liver, and other tissues. Alexion estimates that the drug could eventually have annual sales of more than $1 billion.{{cite news|title=Biotech blastoff: Synageva up 112% on $8B Alexion deal|agency=AP|author=Tom Murphy|work=USA Today|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2015/05/06/alexion-synageva/70909976/|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=May 7, 2015}} ==Financials== In 2013, 36% Alexion's sales originated in the US, down from 37% the previous year; 33% came from Europe, down from 35%; Japan accounted for just over 10%. Revenue was impacted by higher unit volumes for Soliris (up 40%), and a decreased average price related to rebates in Europe. Acquisition related costs fell significantly from $22 million to just $5 million.{{cite web|url=http://ir.alexionpharm.com/secfiling.cfm?filingID=899866-14-34|title=Alexion Pharmaceuticals, Inc. - Annual Report|author=|date=|website=ir.alexionpharm.com}} R&D spending reached a record high of $317 million in 2013 up 83% from the previous year. When Soliris was first approved, peak annual sales were estimated at $150 million. However, by September 2013 quarterly sales of Soliris topped $400 million. Sales during the first quarter of 2015 were just over US$600 million, and are still on the rise.{{cite news|title=Alexion to Buy Synageva for $8.4 Billion|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=May 6, 2015|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/alexion-to-buy-synageva-in-8-4-billion-biotech-deal-1430911447|accessdate=May 7, 2015|author=Chelsey Dulaney}} Before the Synageva purchase announcement, Alexion was valued at $34 billion. The stock is up roughly 800% in the last five years and is currently trading at 46 times estimated earnings. Due to the niche nature of its market and the high cost of Soliris, the company has enjoyed a high profit margin. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.alxn.com Official website] {{Finance links | name = Alexion Pharmaceuticals | symbol = ALXN | sec_cik = ALXN | yahoo = ALXN | google = ALXN }} * [https://stockrow.com/ALXN ALXN on Stockrow] & [http://www.wikinvest.com/stock/Alexion_Pharmaceuticals_(ALXN) Wikinvest] {{NASDAQ-100}} [[Category:Pharmaceutical companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Boston]] [[Category:Health care companies based in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Companies in the NASDAQ-100 Index]] [[Category:Pharmaceutical companies established in 1992]] [[Category:Orphan drug companies]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]] [[Category:Specialty drugs]] [[Category:Biotechnology companies established in 1992]]

revision.text: {{Infobox park | name = Arizona State University Research Park | type = Business Park Recreational Park | location = [[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]], [[Arizona]], [[United States]] | coords = {{Coord|33|20|34|N|111|53|52|W|type:landmark_region:US-AZ|display=inline,title}} | area = 320 acres (1.3 km²) 18 acres for 3 Lakes | operator = [[Arizona State University]] | status = | open = All year }} The '''Arizona State University Research Park''' is a [[business park|business]] and recreational [[park]] that is operated by [[Arizona State University]]. Located in the city of [[Tempe, Arizona]], [[United States]]; the park sits on eastern half of the square mile bordered on the north by East Elliot Road, on the east by the Arizona State Highway: Route Loop 101 Price Freeway, on the south by East Warner Road, and the west by South McClintock Drive. [[Chuck Backus]], formerly vice president and provost of [[Arizona State University's Polytechnic Campus|ASU’s East Campus]], was elected as the President of the ASU Research Park in spring 2005. ==ASU Research Park amenities== *Access to the [[State Route 101 (Arizona)|State Route 101]] Price Freeway *Daycare facility on site *City Buses (Valley Metro) **Route 81 (North-South McClintock/Hayden) **Route 108 (East-West Elliot) **Route 511 (Chandler-Scottsdale Express via State Route 101) *FAA approved helipad *Access to services provided by ASU only for tenants *Three artificial lakes ==List of Companies in the Research Park== *[http://www.aerialsexpress.com Aerials Express] *American PEO, Inc. *[http://www.anadigm.com Anadigm] *[http://www.aseglobal.com ASE] {{Infobox person | name = Bernardo Caprotti | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 7 October 1925 | birth_place = | death_date = 30 September 2016 | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Italian | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = | occupation = owner of [[Esselunga]] | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = | spouse = Giuliana Albera | parents = Giuseppe Caprotti
Marianne Maire | children = 3 | relations = | website = }} '''Bernardo Caprotti''' (7 October 1925 - 30 September 2016) was an Italian [[billionaire]] businessman, the owner of [[Esselunga]], Italy's third-largest grocery store chain.{{cite web|title=The World's Billionaires: Bernardo Caprotti|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/bernardo-caprotti/|website=Forbes|accessdate=23 January 2017}} In his will, he left 66.7% of Esselunga to his second wife Giuliana Albera and their daughter Marina Sylvia, and 16.7% to each of his children from his first marriage, his son Giuseppe Caprotti and his daughter Violetta.{{cite web|url=http://www.italianfood.net/blog/2016/10/11/esselunga-disputed-legacy-italian-supermarket-chain-giant/ |title=Esselunga, the disputed legacy of the Italian retail giant |website=ItalianFood.net |date=2016-10-11 |accessdate=2017-01-23}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Caprotti, Bernardo}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Italian billionaires]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox video game | collapsible = | state = | italic title = | title = C.E.O. | image = | alt = | caption = | developer = [[ERE Informatique]], [[Artdink]] | publisher = [[I-Motion]] | series = | engine = | platforms = [[DOS]] | released = 1995 | genre = | modes = }} '''''C.E.O.''''' is a video game developed by French studio [[ERE Informatique]] and Japanese studio [[Artdink]] and published by [[I-Motion]] for [[DOS]].
==Gameplay== ''C.E.O.'' is a management training game, with features like stocks and subsidiaries.<ref name="NG"/>
==Reception== ''[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]'' reviewed the PC version of the game, rating it two stars out of five, and stated that "When was the last time you saw a real CEO (or anyone for that matter) try to get the busses and trains to run effeciently? This isn't a bad game, but it just doesn't give a good feeling of cohesion."<ref name="NG">{{cite magazine |last= |first= |title=Finals |magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]] |issue=11 |publisher=[[Future US|Imagine Media]] |date=November 1995 |page=179}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=April 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} In the 1990s, a '''trade dispute''' over fresh [[salmon]] arose between [[Canada]] and [[Australia]]. In 1995, Canada made a complaint to the [[World Trade Organization]], of which both countries are members, about Australia's restriction on imports of fresh salmon, which were part of a [[quarantine]] measure for health purposes.
[[Dispute settlement in the World Trade Organization|WTO dispute resolution]] favored Canada, both in a 1997 panel decision and in a subsequent decision by the WTO [[Appellate Body]]. The WTO determined that the [[Agreement on the Application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures]] (SPS Agreement) did not allow Australia's import ban. The WTO ordered Australia to lift its ban and increased quarantine requirements not only for salmon, but for imports of other species of fish as well.<ref name="Importation of Salmon">{{cite web|title=Australia - Measures Affecting Importation of Salmon|url=http://dfat.gov.au/international-relations/international-organisations/wto/wto-dispute-settlement/Pages/australia-measures-affecting-importation-of-salmon-wt-ds18.aspx|website=dfat.gov.au|accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref> The parties settled their dispute in 2000.
==Salmon industry and origins of the dispute== In the 1990s, major world salmon exporters include Canada, Norway, Chile, Scotland, Sweden, Denmark, New Zealand, and Australia.<ref name="Richardson">Michael Richardson, [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/10/business/worldbusiness/10iht-fish.t_0.html Ottawa Sees Protectionism by Canberra; Canada's Beef: Salmon], ''New York Times'', November 10, 1995.</ref> In 1995, Australia had a 100 million [[Australian dollar|AUD]] (75.1 million [[United States dollar|USD]]) salmon industry, with a total value of Australian salmon exports (mostly to east Asia, particularly Japan) of about 40 million dollars.<ref name="Richardson"/>
In 1975, Australia imposed a ban on imports of fresh salmon under a quarantine regulation intended to prevent entry of imported diseases into fish stock in Australia.<ref name="Richardson"/> Australia did allow imports of non-fresh salmon, including salmon that had been heat-treated by [[canning]] (see [[salmon cannery]]) or [[smoking]], which reduces the risk of disease. In 1995, the annual value of such imports to Australia was about 52 million dollars, with almost half of these imports coming from Canada.<ref name="Richardson"/> Australian salmon had an advantage in Japanese and other markets, selling for premiums up to 20 percent over other imported fresh salmon, because of Australian environmental regulations.<ref name="Richardson"/>
In the 1990s, however, tensions arose between Canada and Australia over Australia's regulation, negatively affecting the [[Australia–Canada relations|two countries' relations]].<ref name="Richardson"/> The Australians argued that the ban was justified on health grounds; the Canadians argued that there was no scientific evidence that Canadian fresh-salmon imports would be unsafe and that the ban was simply [[protectionism]].<ref name="Richardson"/>
[[File:Salmon for sale.JPG|thumb|Salmon for sale at a fish market.]]
==WTO case and settlement== In the 1990s, Canada brought a dispute to the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTC) against Australia regarding the importation of salmon. The official title of the case was '''Australia — Measures Affecting Importation of Salmon''', Dispute DS18.<ref name="WTO">[https://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/dispu_e/cases_e/ds18_e.htm Dispute Settlement: Dispute DS18: Australia — Measures Affecting Importation of Salmon], World Trade Organization.</ref> The dispute was the first challenged under the 1994 Agreement on the Application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures (SPS Agreement) reached following the 1994 [[Uruguay Round]].<ref name="Richardson"/>
The case formally began with Canada's request for consultations on October 1995.<ref name="WTO"/> Canada alleged that Australia's prohibition on Canadian salmon imports under the Australian quarantine regulation was inconsistent with the SPS Agreement and articles XI and XIII of the 1994 [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade]] (GATT).<ref name="WTO"/>
Following requests from Canada to establish a panel, the DSB did so in April 1997.<ref name="WTO"/> The [[European Communities]], [[India]], [[Norway]], and the [[United States]] reserved their third-party rights.<ref name="WTO"/> The panel was composed in May 1997, and the panel report circulated in June 1998.<ref name="WTO"/> The panel determined that Australia's important ban was "inconsistent with Articles 2.2, 2.3, 5.1, 5.5, and 5.6 of the SPS Agreement, and also nullified or impaired benefits accruing to Canada under the SPS Agreement."<ref name="WTO"/>
In June 1998, Australia filed a notice of its intention to appeal the panel's decision to the WTO [[Appellate Body]].<ref name="WTO"/> The Appellate Body report circulated in October 1998.<ref name="WTO"/> The Appellate Body reversed the panel with respect to its reasoning on Articles 5.1 and 2.2 of the SPS Agreement, but found that Australia "had acted inconsistently" with those sections.<ref name="WTO"/> The Appellate Body also broadened the panel's determination that Australia had acted inconsistently with Articles 5.5 and 2.3 of the SPS Agreement.<ref name="WTO"/> Finally the Appellate Body "reversed the panel's finding that Australia had acted inconsistently with Article 5.6 of the SPS Agreement but was unable to come to a conclusion whether or not Australia's measure was consistent with Article 5.6 due to insufficient factual findings by the panel."<ref name="WTO"/> The decision directed Australia not only to lift the ban on Canadian salmon, but also the quarantine requirements for several other species of fish.<ref name="Importation of Salmon"/>
The DSB adopted the Appellate Body report and the panel report, as modified by the Appellate Body report in November 1998.<ref name="WTO"/> Australia expressed its intention to abide by the DSB's decision.<ref name="WTO"/>
In December 1998, Canada requested arbitration under to Article 21.3(c) of the Dispute Settlement Understanding (DSU) "to determine the reasonable period of time for implementation of the recommendations of the DSB."<ref name="WTO"/> The Article 21.3(c) Arbitration Report was circulated in February 1999; it determined that the reasonable period of time for implementation was eight months (i.e., the period ending on July 6, 1999).<ref name="WTO"/>
After Canada brought this dispute to the WTO, Australia published the "1999 Import Risk Analysis" arguing that the import of frozen, fresh or chilled salmon is a health risk.<ref>{{cite web|title=Australia-Salmon|url=https://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/dispu_e/cases_e/1pagesum_e/ds18sum_e.pdf|website=wto.org|accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref>
In 1999, Canada made requests under the DSU for a determination by the original panel of whether the implementation measures taken by Australia were consistent with WTO rules as determined in the dispute-resolution proceedings.<ref name="WTO"/> At its meeting of July 28, 1999, the DSB agreed to take up Canada's request and referred the matter back to the original panel. The EC, Norway and the U.S. again reserved their third-party rights.<ref name="WTO"/>
The compliance panel was composed in September 1999 and circulated its report in February 2000, finding:<ref name="WTO"/>
{{quote|
*Due to delays in the entry into force of several implementing measures which extended beyond the reasonable period of time within which Australia had to implement the DSB recommendations, no measures to comply existed in the sense of Article 21.5 of the DSU in respect of a number of covered products and during specific periods of time. As a result, during those periods, Australia failed to bring its measure into conformity with the SPS Agreement in the sense referred to in Article 22.6 of the DSU. *Australia, by requiring that only salmon product that is "consumer-ready" as specifically defined can be imported into Australia and released from quarantine, was maintaining sanitary measures that were not "based on" a risk assessment, which was contrary to Articles 5.1 and 2.2 of the SPS Agreement. The panel also considered the same requirement to be in violation of Article 5.6 of the SPS Agreement. *Finally, the panel found that Australia violated Articles 5.1 and 2.2 of the SPS Agreement as a result of a measure enacted by the Government of Tasmania that effectively prohibits the importation of certain Canadian salmon product into most parts of Tasmania without being based on a risk assessment and without sufficient scientific evidence.<ref name="WTO"/>}}
The DSB adopted the report of the compliance panel in March 2000.<ref name="WTO"/>
In July 1999, before compliance proceedings began, Canada requested authorization from the DSB, pursuant to Article 22.2 of the DSU, to suspend concessions to Australia because of its non-compliance.<ref name="WTO"/> Australia objected to Canada's proposed level of suspension of concessions and requested that the matter be referred to arbitration, pursuant to Article 22.6.<ref name="WTO"/> The DSB agreed to this request, but the arbitration proceedings were suspended until after the compliance proceedings concluded.<ref name="WTO"/>
At the DSB meeting of May 18, 2000, following the compliance panel's decision, and following discussion between the WTO and the governments of the two countries, sectors of each government and the panel, Canada announced that it had come to an agreement with Australia to bring the dispute to a close.<ref name="Importation of Salmon"/><ref name="WTO"/> The parties exchanged letters detailing the agreement.<ref name="WTO"/> Under the agreement, "Canada would monitor closely Australia's commitment to implement the agreement" by June 1, 2000.<ref name="Importation of Salmon"/><ref name="WTO"/> The agreement became effective on schedule on June 1, 2000.<ref name="Importation of Salmon"/>
==Countries ==
=== Canada ===
The [[Canadian Food Inspection Agency]] (CFIA) verifies that exported foods and food products meet the Canadian standards just as an importing country would. Countries have their own requirements for foods and food products and the Canadian government understands this and respects those requirements.<ref name=CFIA>{{cite web|title=Food Exports|url=http://www.inspection.gc.ca/food/exports/eng/1323723342834/1323723662195|website=www.inspection.gc.ca|accessdate=12 December 2017|date=17 November 2017}}</ref> Canada has implemented the fish inspection act to help regulate the export of fish and fish products.<ref name="Fish Export Policy">{{cite web|title=Fish Export Policy|url=http://www.inspection.gc.ca/food/fish-and-seafood/exports/policy/eng/1329762426884/1329762515816|website=www.inspection.gc.ca|accessdate=12 December 2017|date=27 September 2013}}</ref> The efforts Canada has put towards achieving a substantial export in their fish (salmon) shows speculation towards Australia.
=== Australia ===
[[Aquaculture in Australia]] is the country's fastest growing [[primary industry]] accounting for 34% of the countries seafood production. Salmon is a part of this movement across the country with Atlantic salmon becoming a mainstream fish produced through the aquaculture systems. Salmon farms are found in [[Tasmania]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and [[South Australia]] and while they are making an effort to improve [[salmon farming]] offshore and inshore it is still producing a small amount of salmon for Australia.
Although the countries were developing a negative trade relationship, Australia values its long-standing close and productive relationship with Canada. Their trade relationship dates back over 100 years and the two countries continuously work together. Australian and Canadian military forces fought side by side in both World Wars, The Korean War and the 1990-91 Gulf War. Both countries have forces in Afghanistan making movements to stabilize that country as close military allies.<ref name="Australia-Canada Relations">{{cite web|title=Australia-Canada relations|url=http://www.canada.embassy.gov.au/otwa/relations.html|website=www.canada.embassy.gov.au|accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Canadian Food Inspection Agency]] *[[Aquaculture in Australia]] *[[Food safety]] *[[Fishery]] *[[Aquaculture of salmonids]] *[[Salmon as food]] *[[Australia-Canada relations]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links ==
Relevant articles of the SPS Agreement * [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/booksp_e/analytic_index_e/sps_02_e.htm#article5A1 Sections 5.1, 5.5, 5.6] * [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/booksp_e/analytic_index_e/sps_01_e.htm#article2A3 Section 2.2]

page.title: Castillo v. Case Farms of Ohio

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/137.195.224.138|137.195.224.138]] to version by Bri. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3525428) (Bot)
revision.text:
{| class="infobox" style="width: 25em; font-size: 95%;" |- ! colspan="2" bgcolor="6699FF" | '''''Castillo v. Case Farms of Ohio''''' |- | colspan="2" align="center" | '''[[United States District Court for the Western District of Texas]]''' |- |'''Filed''' | |- |'''Decided''' |December 1, 1999 |- |'''Case name''' |''Castillo v. Case Farms of Ohio'' |- |'''Citations''' |''96 F. Supp. 2d 578'' | |- |'''Holding''' |Labor Agency is an agent for farm. Farm is liable for wrongful actions of the labor agency. |- |'''Judge''' | Senior District Judge | | |- |'''Laws applied''' |[[Agency (law)]] |} '''''Castillo v. Case Farms of Ohio''''', 96 F Supp. 2d 578, is a case involving poor working conditions for migratory workers. It established that an [[Agency (law)|principal / agent]] relationship existed between Case Farms and America's Tempcorps (ATC) that allowed Case Farms to be liable for its agent's actions.
==Facts== [[Migrant workers|Migrant farm workers]] were recruited in Texas by America's Tempcorps to work in Case Farm's [[Ohio]]-based chicken processing plant. They were given a bus ticket and $20 for three days of food. Upon arriving they found themselves living in conditions called "distressing and deplorable" by the court. The employees were packed in to unfurnished rooms infested with cockroaches and rats. The workers slept on the floor and were transported in an overcrowded van.
==Issue== The working conditions were largely not refuted. At issue was 1) whether or not American's Tempcorps (ATC) was an agent of Case Farms, and 2) if agency existed, whether that agency make Case Farms liable for ATC’s actions.
==Complaint== The plaintiffs alleged: *Violations of the [[Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Workers Protection Act]] (AWPA) *Violations of the [[Fair Labor Standards Act]] *[[Breach of Contract]] *[[Fraud]] *[[Negligence|Negligent]] Misrepresentation
==Plaintiff’s Argument== Castillo argued that agency relationship existed between ATC and Case Farms, and the scope of that relationship included both the [[Agency (law)|express authority]] to recruit and hire people to work at Case Farms’ plant, and the [[Agency (law)|implied authority]] to do all things proper, usual and necessary to exercise that authority.
==Defendant’s Argument== Case Farms argued, to the extent that an agency relationship existed, the scope of that agency was limited solely to informing recruits about the availability of work at Case Farms’ processing plant. They also contended that the workers recruited by ATC were not full-fledged Case Farms workers (despite the fact that the work, pay rates, and supervision of these workers were essentially identical to Case Farms employees.)
== The Court's Analysis == 1) A principal may be liable for the acts of a purported agent based on an actual agency relationship created by the principal’s express or implied delegation of authority to the agent.
2) A principal is liable only if those actions are taken in the scope of the agent’s employment. Express actual authority exists “where the principal has made it clear to the agent that he wants the act under scrutiny to be done.”
3) Giving an agent express authority to undertake a certain act also includes the implied authority to do all things proper, usual, and necessary to exercise that express authority.
The evidence at trial supported the contention that Case Farms expressly authorized ATC to recruit and hire people to work at Case Farms’ Ohio plant, and that such an express agency existed with the scope of recruiting and hiring migrant workers. The evidence also supported the contention that the housing and transportation activities were well within the agents implied authority—based on Case Farms’ unique recruiting challenges, the great distances the migrant workers sought were required to travel, and Case Farms outsourcing of this difficult recruiting task to ATC.
== Holding == America's Tempcorps was an agent of Case Farms, ATC’s actions were attributable to Case Farms for the purpose of assessing compliance with the [[Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act|AWPA]], and Case Farms was liable for ATC’s actions..
==References== {{Reflist}} *96 F Supp. 2d 578 * {{cite book | last1=Smith | first1=Gordon | last2=Williams | first2=Cynthia| title=Business Organizations - Cases, Problems and Case Studies | edition=2nd | isbn=978-0-7355-7140-2 | publisher=Aspen Publishers }}
[[Category:Agency law]] [[Category:United States district court cases]] [[Category:United States labor case law]] [[Category:1999 in United States case law]]

The '''Daniel Guggenheim Medal''' is an American [[engineering]] award, established by [[Daniel Guggenheim|Daniel]] and [[Harry Guggenheim]]. The medal is considered to be one of the greatest honors that can be presented for a lifetime of work in [[aeronautics]].<ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Home.aspx History of Guggenheim medal]</ref> Recipients have included American and international individuals from aeronautical corporations, governments, and academia.
Since 1929 it has been given annually to persons who make notable achievements in the advancement of aeronautics.<ref>[http://www.aiaa.org/content.cfm?pageid=401 Guggenheim award] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050424160935/http://www.aiaa.org/content.cfm?pageid=401 |date=2005-04-24 }}</ref> It is awarded jointly by the [[American Society of Mechanical Engineers]], the [[Society of Automotive Engineers]], the [[American Helicopter Society]], and the [[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics]]. The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics administers the award.
==Recipients== The winners are listed below along with their award citation and year.
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%" ! width="15%" | Year ! width="20%" | Name ! width="*" class="unsortable" | Award citation ! width="5%" class="unsortable" | Reference |- | 1929 | align="center" | [[Orville Wright]] | ''For the design and construction, with his brother now deceased, of the first successful engine-propelled airplane.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201929.pdf Orville Wright - 1929 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1930 | align="center" | [[Ludwig Prandtl]] | ''For pioneer and creative work in the theory of dynamics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201930.pdf Ludwig Prandtl - 1930 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1931 | align="center" | [[Frederick W. Lanchester]] | ''For contributions to the fundamental theory of [[aerodynamics]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201931.pdf Frederick W. Lanchester - 1931 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1932 | align="center" | [[Juan de la Cierva]] | ''For development of the theory and practice of the [[autogiro]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201932.pdf Juan de la Cierva - 1932 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1933 | align="center" | [[Jerome Clarke Hunsaker]] | ''For contributions to the science of aerodynamics, to the science and art of aircraft design, and to the practical construction and utilization of rigid airships.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201933.pdf Jerome C. Hunsaker - 1933 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1934 | align="center" | [[William E. Boeing]] | ''For successful pioneering and achievement in aircraft manufacturing and air transport.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201934.pdf William E. Boeing - 1934 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1935 | align="center" | [[William F. Durand]] | ''For notable achievement as pioneer in laboratory research and theory of aeronautics; distinguished contributions to the theory and development of aircraft [[propeller]]s.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201935.pdf William F. Durand - 1935 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1936 | align="center" | [[George W. Lewis]] | ''For pioneer and creative work in the theory of dynamics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201936.pdf George W. Lewis - 1936 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1937 | align="center" | [[Hugo Eckener]] | ''For notable contributions to transoceanic air transport and to international cooperation in aeronautics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201937.pdf Hugo Eckener - 1937 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1938 | align="center" | [[Roy Fedden|Alfred H. Fedden]] | ''For contributions to the development of aircraft engine design and for the specific design of the [[Sleeve valve|sleeve-valve]] aircraft engine.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201938.pdf Alfred Fedden - 1938 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1939 | align="center" | [[Donald W. Douglas]] | ''For outstanding contributions to the design and construction of transport airplanes.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201939.pdf Donald W. Douglas - 1939 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1940 | align="center" | [[Glenn L. Martin]] | ''For contributions to aeronautical development and the production of many types of aircraft of high performance.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201940.pdf Glenn L. Martin - 1940 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1941 | align="center" | [[Juan T. Trippe]] | ''For the development and successful operation of oceanic air transport.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201941.pdf Juan T. Trippe - 1941 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1942 | align="center" | [[James H. Doolittle]] | ''For notable achievements in the advancements of both the art and the science of aeronautics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201942.pdf James H. Doolittle - 1942 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1943 | align="center" | [[Edmund T. "Eddie" Allen]] | ''For major contributions to aeronautics leading to important advances in airplane design, flight research, and airline operation; particularly for the presentation of new methods for operational control and for the development of scientific and systematic methods in the flight testing of aircraft for basic design and performance data.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201943.pdf Edmund T. Allen - 1943 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1944 | align="center" | [[Lawrence D. Bell]] | ''For achievement in design and construction of military air craft and for outstanding contributions to the methods of production.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201944.pdf Lawrence D. Bell - 1944 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1945 | align="center" | [[Theodore P. Wright]] | ''For outstanding contributions to the development of civil and military aircraft, and for notable achievement in assuring the success of our wartime aircraft production program.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201945.pdf Theodore P. Wright - 1945 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1946 | align="center" | [[Frank Whittle]] | ''For pioneering the development of [[turbojet]] propulsion of aircraft.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201946.pdf Frank Whittle - 1946 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1947 | align="center" | [[d:Q36071124|Lester Durand Gardner]] | ''For outstanding achievement in advancing aeronautics, particularly for his conception and organization of the [[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics|Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201947.pdf Lester D. Gardner - 1947 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1948 | align="center" | [[Leroy R. Grumman]] | ''For outstanding achievement in successfully advancing aircraft design, both for Naval and peacetime use.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201948.pdf Leroy R. Grumman - 1948 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1949 | align="center" | [[Edward Pearson Warner]] | ''For pioneering in research and a continuous record of contributions to the art and science of aeronautics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201949.pdf Edward P. Warner - 1949 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1950 | align="center" | [[Hugh L. Dryden]] | ''For outstanding leadership in aeronautical research and fundamental contributions to aeronautical science.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201950.pdf Hugh L. Dryden - 1950 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1951 | align="center" | [[Igor I. Sikorsky]] | ''For a lifetime of outstanding contributions to aeronautics, including pioneering with multi-engine airplanes, [[flying boat]]s, [[Amphibious aircraft|amphibians]] and [[helicopter]]s.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201951.pdf Igor I. Sikorsky - 1951 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1952 | align="center" | [[Geoffrey de Havilland]] | ''For forty years of pioneering in military and commercial aircraft and the development of long-range jet transport.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201952.pdf Geoffrey de Havilland - 1952 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1953 | align="center" | [[Charles Lindbergh]] | ''For pioneering achievements in flight and air navigation.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201953.pdf Charles Lindbergh - 1953 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1954 | align="center" | [[C. Howe - 1954 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1955 | align="center" | [[Theodore von Karman]] | ''For long-continued leadership in the development of aerodynamic theory and its application to the practical problems of flight, in education in the aeronautical sciences, and in stimulating international cooperation in aeronautical research.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201955.pdf Theodore von Karman - 1955 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1956 | align="center" | [[Frederick B. Rentschler - 1956 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1957 | align="center" | [[Arthur E. Goddard - 1964 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1965 | align="center" | [[Sydney Camm]] | ''For over fifty years of continuous dedication to the design of military aircraft, and pioneering of many new concepts and the creation of many successful aircraft representative of the best tradition of British design skills.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Camm Sydney Camm - 1965 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1966 | align="center" | [[Charles S. Covert - 2005 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2006 | align="center" | [[Robert Loewy]] | ''For pioneering contributions to rotary-wing aeroelasticity and unsteady aerodynamics which had an enormous influence on rotary-wing technology and his contributions to education and public service in aeronautics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=loewy Robert Loewy - 2006 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2007 | align="center" | [[Alexander H. Flax]] | ''For outstanding contributions to aerospace engineering in aeroelasticity, unsteady aerodynamics and flight mechanics, and for exceptional leadership of engineering organizations including service to the [[United States Department of Defense|U.S. Department of Defense]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Flax Alexander Flax - 2007 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2008 | align="center" | [[Earl Dowell]] | ''For pioneering contributions to nonlinear aeroelasticity, structural dynamics and unsteady aerodynamics which had a significant influence on aeronautics and for contributions to education and public service in aerospace engineering.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://prattpress.pratt.duke.edu/dowell-wins-award Earl Dowell - 2008 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2009 | align="center" | [[Arthur E. Bryson]] | ''For a lifetime of seminal contributions to real systems, creating and applying practical optimal control and estimation techniques to airplanes, rotorcraft, and missiles.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://aa.stanford.edu/news/brysonAward.php Arthur E. Bryson - 2009 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2010 | align="center" | [[Robert H. Liebeck]] | ''For distinguished engineering as evidenced by the conception and development of Liebeck airfoils and [[Blended wing body|Blended Wing Body aircraft]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2010/liebeck-guggenheim.html Liebeck to receive Guggenheim Medal]</ref> |- | 2011 | align="center" | [[Burt Rutan]] | ''For a distinguished career of highly innovative and successful flight vehicles ranging from home-built designed to Voyager and SpaceShipOne.'' | align="center" | |- | 2012 | align="center" | [[Frank D. Robinson]] | ''For conception, design, and manufacture of a family of quiet, affordable, reliable, and versatile helicopters.'' | align="center" | |- | 2013 | align="center" | [[Abraham Karem]] | ''For a lifetime of innovative fixed and rotary wing unmanned vehicle designs.'' | align="center" | |- | 2014 | align="center" | [[Alan Mulally]] | ''For leadership in the creation, design, development, and manufacture of commercial airplanes, exemplified by the Boeing 777.'' | align="center" | |- | 2015 | align="center" | [[Antony Jameson]] | ''For exceptional contributions to algorithmic innovation and the development of computational fluid dynamic codes that have made important contributions to aircraft design.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://aa.stanford.edu/news-events/news/antony-jameson-joins-orville-wright-and-other-aerial-pioneers-winning-guggenheim Antony Jameson - 2015 Medalist]</ref> |}

revision.comment: Alter: template type. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
'''Decision-making software''' ('''DM software''') is a term for computer applications that help individuals and organisations make choices and take decisions, typically by ranking, prioritizing or choosing from a number of options.
An early example of DM software was described in 1973.<ref name="Dyer">Dyer, JS (1973), "A time-sharing computer program for the solution of the multiple criteria problem", ''Management Science'', 19: 1379-83.</ref><ref name="Walleniusetal">Wallenius, J, Dyer, JS, Fishburn, PC, Steuer, RE, Zionts, S and Deb, K (1992), "Multiple criteria decision making, multiattribute utility theory: The next ten years", ''Management Science'', 38: 645-54.</ref> Before the advent of the [[World Wide Web]], most DM software was spreadsheet-based,<ref name="Walleniusetal" /> with the first web-based DM software appearing in the mid-1990s.<ref name="Koksalanetal">Koksalan, M, Wallenius, J, and Zionts, S, ''Multiple Criteria Decision Making: From Early History to the 21st Century'', World Scientific Publishing: Singapore, 2011.</ref> Nowadays, many DM software products (mostly web-based) are available<ref name="Weistrofferetal">Weistroffer, HR, and Li, Y, "Multiple criteria decision analysis software", Ch 29 in: Greco, S, Ehrgott, M and Figueira, J, eds, ''Multiple Criteria Decision Analysis: State of the Art Surveys Series'', Springer: New York, 2016.</ref><ref name="orms">Oleson, S (2016), [http://www.orms-today.org/surveys/das/das.html "Decision analysis software survey"], ''OR/MS Today'' 43(5).</ref><ref name="Ishizaka">{{Cite book | doi = 10.1002/9781118644898| title = Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis| year = 2013| last1 = Ishizaka | first1 = A. | last2 = Nemery | first2 = P. | isbn = 9781118644898}}</ref> – e.g. see the comparison table below.
Most DM software focuses on ranking, prioritizing or choosing from among alternatives characterized on multiple criteria or attributes.<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /> Thus most DM software is based on [[decision analysis]], usually [[multi-criteria decision-making]], and so is often referred to as "decision analysis"<ref name="orms" /> or "multi-criteria decision-making"<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /> software – commonly shortened to "decision-making software". Some [[decision support systems]] include a DM software component.
==Purpose== DM software can assist decision-makers “at various stages of the decision-making process, including problem exploration and formulation, identification of decision alternatives and solution constraints, structuring of preferences, and tradeoff judgements.”<ref name="Weistrofferetal" />
The purpose of DM software is to support the analysis involved at these various stages of the decision-making process, not to replace it. DM software "should be used to support the process, not as the driving or dominating force."<ref name="BeltonandStewart">Belton, V, and Stewart, TJ, ''Multiple Criteria Decision Analysis: An Integrated Approach'', Kluwer: Boston, 2002.</ref>
DM software frees users "from the technical implementation details [of the decision-making method employed], allowing them to focus on the fundamental value judgements".<ref name="BeltonandStewart" /> Nonetheless, DM software should not be employed blindly. "Before using a software, it is necessary to have a sound knowledge of the adopted methodology and of the decision problem at hand."<ref name="Figueiraetal">Figueira, J, Greco, S and Ehrgott, M, "Introduction", Ch 1 in: Figueira, J, Greco, S and Ehrgott, M, eds, ''Multiple Criteria Decision Analysis: State of the Art Surveys Series'', Springer: New York, 2005.</ref>
==Methods and features==
===Decision-making methods=== As mentioned earlier, most DM software is based on [[multi-criteria decision making]] (MCDM). MCDM involves evaluating and combining alternatives' characteristics on two or more criteria or attributes in order to rank, prioritize or choose from among the alternatives.<ref name="Walleniusetal2008">Wallenius, J, Dyer, JS, Fishburn, PC, Steuer, RE, Zionts, S and Deb, K (2008), "Multiple criteria decision making, multiattribute utility theory: Recent accomplishments and what lies ahead", ''Management Science'' 54: 1336-49.</ref>
DM software employs a variety of MCDM methods;<ref name="BeltonandStewart" /> popular examples include: * [[Aggregated Indices Randomization Method]] (AIRM) * [[Analytic Hierarchy Process]] (AHP) * [[Analytic network process]] (ANP, an extension of AHP) * [[ELECTRE|Elimination and Choice Expressing Reality]] (ELECTRE) * [[Measuring Attractiveness by a Categorical Based Evaluation Technique (MACBETH)]] * [[Multi-attribute global inference of quality]] (MAGIQ) * [[Potentially All Pairwise RanKings of all possible Alternatives]] (PAPRIKA) * [[Preference Ranking Organization Method for Enrichment Evaluation]] (PROMETHEE) * [[Evidential reasoning approach]] for MCDM under hybrid uncertainty
There are significant differences between these methods<ref name="BeltonandStewart" /><ref name="Walleniusetal2008" /> and, accordingly, the DM software implementing them. Such differences include: :# The extent to which the decision problem is broken into a [[hierarchy]] of sub-problems; :# Whether or not [[pairwise comparisons]] of alternatives and/or criteria are used to elicit decision-makers' preferences; :# The use of [[interval scale]] or [[ratio scale]] measurements of decision-makers' preferences; :# The number of criteria included; :# The number of alternatives evaluated, ranging from a few (finite) to infinite; :# The extent to which numerical scores are used to value and/or rank alternatives; :# The extent to which incomplete rankings (relative to complete rankings) of alternatives are produced; :# The extent to which uncertainty is modeled and analyzed.
===Software features=== In the process of helping decision-makers to rank, prioritize or choose from among alternatives, DM software products often include a variety of features and tools;<ref name="Koksalanetal" /><ref name="Weistrofferetal" /> common examples include: *[[Pairwise comparison]] *[[Sensitivity analysis]] *Group evaluation (teamwork) *Web-based implementation
===Comparison of decision-making software=== DM software includes the following notable examples.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Software !! Supported [[MCDA]] Methods !! Pairwise Comparison !! Sensitivity Analysis !! Group Evaluation !! Web-based |- | [[1000minds]] || [[Potentially all pairwise rankings of all possible alternatives|PAPRIKA]] || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} ||<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /><ref name="orms" /> |- | [[Ahoona]] || [[Weighted sum model|WSM]], [[Utility]] || {{No}} || {{No}}|| {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} ||<ref>http://create.usc.edu/sites/default/files/publications//dmsocialnetworkswithcover.pdf</ref> |- | [[MetaTeam|Altova MetaTeam]] || [[Weighted sum model|WSM]] || {{No}} || {{No}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} |- | [[Analytica (software)|Analytica]] || || {{No}} || {{Yes}}|| {{No}} || {{Yes}} ||<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /><ref name="orms" /> |- | [[Criterium DecisionPlus]] || [[Analytic Hierarchy Process|AHP]], SMART || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{No}} || {{No}} ||<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /> |- | [[D-Sight]] || [[Preference ranking organization method for enrichment evaluation|PROMETHEE]], UTILITY || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} ||<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /><ref name="orms" /> |- | [[DecideIT]] || MAUT || {{Yes}}|| {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} ||<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /><ref name="orms" /> |- | [[Decision Lens]] || [[Analytic Hierarchy Process|AHP]], [[Analytic network process|ANP]] || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} |- | [[Expert Choice]] || [[Analytic Hierarchy Process|AHP]] || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} ||<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /><ref name="orms" /> |- | [[Hiview3]] || || {{No}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{No}} ||<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /><ref name="orms" /> |- | [[Intelligent Decision System]] || [[Evidential Reasoning Approach]], [[Bayesian Inference]], [[Dempster–Shafer theory]], Utility || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || Available on request ||<ref name="orms" /> |- | [[Logical Decisions]] || [[Analytic Hierarchy Process|AHP]] || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{No}} ||<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /><ref name="orms" /> |- | [[Measuring Attractiveness by a Categorical Based Evaluation Technique (MACBETH)|M-MACBETH]] || [[Measuring Attractiveness by a Categorical Based Evaluation Technique (MACBETH)|MACBETH]] || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{Yes}} || {{No}} ||<ref name="Weistrofferetal" /> |- | revision.comment: removed [[Category:People from Cass County, Michigan]]; added [[Category:People from Dowagiac, Michigan]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Dickinson H. Bishop |image = File:DickinsonHBishop.jpg |image_size = |caption = Undated photo |birth_date = {{birth date|1887|3|24|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Dowagiac, Michigan]], U.S. |death_date = {{death date and age|1961|2|16|1887|3|24|df=y}} |death_place = [[Ottawa, Illinois]], U.S. |occupation = Businessman |known_for = Titanic survivor |spouse = Mary Lee,
Helen Walton,
Sydney Boyce }} '''Dickinson H. Bishop''' (March 24, 1887 – February 16, 1961) was an American businessman who traveled on board the ill-fated maiden voyage of the [[RMS Titanic|RMS ''Titanic'']] while on his honeymoon with bride Helen, ''[[née]]'' Walton. They both survived the [[Sinking of the RMS Titanic|sinking of the ''Titanic'']] on 15 April 1912. ==Early life== Bishop was born in [[Dowagiac, Michigan]], son of George and Virginia Bishop.[http://www.titanicpages.com/1stclass/dickinsonbishop Dickinson Bishop - Titanic First Class Passenger], Titanic Pages. He was 24 when he married Mary Beckwith Lee, an heiress who died in 1910 thirteen days after giving birth to a daughter; the infant died minutes after being born.{{cite book|last1=Arseneau|first1=Steven|title=Dowagiac|year=2005|publisher=Arcadia|location=Charleston, SC|isbn=0738534226|page=71|url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=N5aIFtDL-EUC&pg=PA71 |last2=Thompson|first2=Ann}} Bishop married his second wife, Helen Walton, in November 1911;{{cite web |url=http://www.sturgisjournal.com/article/20120414/NEWS/304149985 |title=Sturgis native survived Titanic's sinking|first=Rosalie|last=Currier|date=14 April 2012|accessdate=8 February 2014|work=[[Sturgis Journal]]}} their four-month honeymoon was to Europe and North Africa, arranging the return on the ''Titanic''. During their trip, Helen became pregnant, and they acquired a dog named Freu Freu while traveling in Italy. ==''Titanic''== ;Voyage The Bishops boarded the ''Titanic'' at [[Cherbourg, France]] as First-class passengers on 10 April 1912. Late on the night of the 14th, the Bishops were in their stateroom when the ''Titanic'' struck an iceberg. Soon after, according to Dickinson Bishop, he went on deck to investigate and subsequently returned to the room after being told by stewards that the ship was in no danger. Later, fellow passenger Albert Stewart convinced the Bishops of the danger, and they returned to the boat deck, leaving Freu Freu behind. Although there was no sense of urgency at that point, they both were told to board [[Lifeboats of the RMS Titanic#Boat 7 (starboard)|lifeboat #7]]. In a newspaper interview, Helen Bishop stated that when they went on deck, someone said the newly married couples should be put into the lifeboat first and that there were three newlywed couples in their boat.{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/bishop-interview-concerning-titanic-disaster.html|title=Mr. and Mrs. Bishop Give First Authentic Interview Concerning Titantic [sic] Disaster|date=April 20, 1912|work=Dowagiac Daily News|accessdate=January 19, 2014}} However, this was not mentioned during her later testimony at the US Inquiry into the disaster. Boat 7 was the first to be lowered from the ''Titanic'', being launched at about 12:45 am on the early morning of the 15th, and was rescued by the {{RMS|Carpathia||2}} sometime after 4:10 am. The Bishops, along with other survivors, were transported to [[New York City]] aboard the ''Carpathia''. ;Inquiry Once in New York, the couple was ordered to report to the Senate Board of Inquiry in Washington D.C. Helen Bishop testified first, stating that she was conversing with Mr. and Mrs. [[John Jacob Astor]] prior to the ship's sinking, when [[Edward Smith (sea captain)|Captain Smith]] came to speak to Mr. Astor. Astor told the group he was talking with to put on life belts and go on deck. Once on deck, an officer took Mrs. Bishop by the arm and told her to quietly get into the lifeboat; after that, her husband was pushed into the boat with her. Helen Bishop said there were 12 women, 13 men and three crew members in the lifeboat; she continued by saying many of the men in the boat were not married.{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/bishops-go-senate-board-inquiry-give-story-titanic-disaster.html|title=Bishops Go Before Senate Board of Inquiry To Give Story Of Titanic Disaster|date=April 26, 1912|work=Dowagiac Daily News|accessdate=January 19, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.titanicinquiry.org/USInq/AmInq11BishopH01.php|title=Testimony of Helen Bishop before the United States Senate Inquiry|date=April 30, 1912|publisher=United States Senate|accessdate=January 19, 2014}} Dickinson Bishop's testimony mainly dealt with the inability to lock the ship's watertight compartments. He recalled the sailors trying to turn the locks and not being able to close them properly on either side of the ship. Bishop also said that he heard no orders to keep the men out of the lifeboats in favor of women and children.{{cite web|url=http://www.titanicinquiry.org/USInq/AmInq11BishopD01.php |title=Testimony of Dickinson H. Bishop before the United States Senate Inquiry|date=April 30, 1912|publisher=United States Senate|accessdate=January 19, 2014}} Bishop was later rumored to have dressed as a woman to get his spot in the lifeboat; this rumor, in part, led to the divorce of the couple.{{cite web |url=http://www.mlive.com/news/kalamazoo/index.ssf/2012/04/southwest_michigan_newlywed_di.html |title=Titanic tale: Southwest Michigan newlyweds survived ship's sinking but did not live happily ever after|first=Julie|last=Mack|date=7 April 2012|accessdate=8 February 2014|work=[[Booth Newspapers|MLive]]}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BfuRDQnYYasC&pg=PT297|title=Unsinkable: The Full Story of the RMS Titanic|editor-last=Butler|editor-first=Daniel Allen|year=2012|publisher=Da Capo Press|isbn= 9780306821035}} On 8 December 1912, Helen gave birth to a boy, Randall Walton Bishop, who died two days afterward. ==Later life== In November 1914, the couple suffered a serious car accident in which Helen was badly injured, and where Dickinson suffered only minor injuries. Helen Bishop's head injuries were so severe, they were reported as being fatal by ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/titanic-survivor-dying.html|title=Titanic Survivor Dying|first=Mark|last=Baber|date=14 November 1914|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=January 19, 2014}} In an attempt to save Helen's life, her doctors tried what was then a new technique: a metal plate was affixed to her skull to cover the badly injured area.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rv1gZo3P0S0C&pg=PA144|title=Shadow of the Titanic: The Extraordinary Stories of Those Who Survived|editor-last=Wilson|editor-first=Andrew|year=2012|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=9781451671582}} In January 1916, Dickinson and Helen divorced. Charging her husband with cruelty and drunkenness, Helen Bishop was granted a divorce and $100,000 in alimony.{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/michigan-wife-gets-100000-alimony.html|title=Michigan Wife Gets $100,000 Alimony|first=Thomas E. |last=Golembiewski|date=18 January 1916|work=[[Chicago's American|Chicago Examiner]]|accessdate=January 19, 2014}} She died two months later, on March 16, 1916, after falling at a friend's home on a visit to [[Danville, Illinois]].{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/bishop-death.html|title=Titanic Survivor Dies In Danville|year=1916|work=Unidentified newspaper|accessdate=January 19, 2014}} Dickinson married his third wife, Sydney Boyce, a daughter of [[William D. Boyce]], two days before the death of his second wife, Helen. The announcements of Dickinson's remarriage and Helen's death were both front page stories of the ''Dowagiac Daily News'' on the same day. He served in the [[U.S. Army|Army]] during the [[First World War]]. Bishop remained married to Sydney Boyce until her death in November 1950. After the end of the war, he moved away from Dowagiac and settled in [[Ottawa, Illinois]] where he died from a [[stroke]] on February 16, 1961.{{cite web |url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/titanic-survivor/dickinson-bishop.html |title=Mr Dickinson H. Bishop|work=[[Encyclopedia Titanica]]|year=2013|accessdate=8 February 2014}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{RMS Titanic}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bishop, Dickinson}} [[Category:1887 births]] [[Category:1961 deaths]] [[Category:RMS Titanic's crew and passengers]] [[Category:RMS Titanic survivors]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Ottawa, Illinois]] [[Category:People from Dowagiac, Michigan]]
