revision.text:
{{Cleanup|date=August 2009}} '''João Pavão Martins''' is a [[Full Professor]] of [[Computer Science and Engineering]] in [[Instituto Superior Técnico]] (Technical University of Lisbon).
He was one of the persons behind the creation of the Computer Science and Engineering degree of Instituto Superior Técnico in 1988, and one of the founders of the Department of [[Computer Science and Engineering]] at the same institute in 1998.
Between 2002 and 2004 he was the head of this Department and again in 2009, for a two-year term.[https://fenix.ist.utl.pt/homepage/ist11416 Technical University of Lisbon Computer Science and Engineering Departament ] He is also a [[software industry]] [[entrepreneur]].
In 1986, together with [[Ernesto Morgado]], he founded [[SISCOG]] - Sistemas Cognitivos, SA, a [[Startup company|start up]] company devoted to the applications of [[Artificial Intelligence]]. Together they led the company to develop and deploy a series of complex [[software]] systems in [[railway]] and [[Rapid transit|metro]] companies throughout the [[world]]. These systems plan and manage more than 20,000 people, affect the life of millions of passengers, and have been awarded by several prestigious organisations in Europe and the United States. João Pavão Martins has a [[Licentiate degree]] in [[Mechanical Engineering]] (1976) from [[Instituto Superior Técnico]] (Technical University of Lisbon), a [[Master of Science]] in [[Computer Science]] (1979) and a [[Ph.D.]] in Artificial Intelligence (1983) from [[University at Buffalo, The State University of New York|State University of New York at Buffalo]]. ==Publications== João Pavão Martins is also an [[author]] and co-author of the following publications: * EPIA-89 Proceedings, Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence, Vol. 390, Heidelberg, West Germany: Springer-Verlag, 1989 (Martins, J.P. e Morgado, E.M.)[https://www.amazon.com/EPIA89-Portuguese-Conference-Intelligence-Proceedings/dp/3540516654 EPIA-89 Proceedings]
* Introduction to computer Science using PASCAL, Wadsworth Inc., 1989 (Martins, J. P.) {{cite web|url= http://www.abebooks.com/book-search/isbn/0534094023/|title= Introduction to computer Science using PASCAL}}
* An AI-Based Approach to Crew Scheduling, Proc. IEEE Conference on AI Applications - CAIA 93, 1993 (Martins, J.P. e Morgado, E.M.) {{cite web|url= http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/login.jsp?tp=&arnumber=366659&url=http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fxpls%2Fabs_all.jsp%3Farnumber%3D366659|title= An AI-Based Approach to Crew Scheduling}}
* Introdução à Programação usando o PASCAL, McGraw-Hill Portugal, 1994 (Martins, J. P.) [http://catalogo.bnportugal.pt/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=1248P4798R734.276121&profile=bn&uri=link=3100027~!7562619~!3100024~!3100022&aspect=basic_search&menu=search&ri=1&source=~!bnp&term=Introdu%C3%A7%C3%A3o+%C3%A0+programa%C3%A7%C3%A3o+usando+o+Pascal&index=ALTITLE#focus Introdução à Programação usando o PASCAL (Portuguese National Library)]
* Programação em scheme, IST Press, 2004 (Martins, J. P. and Cravo, Maria dos Remédios )[http://istpress.ist.utl.pt/lscheme.htm Programação em Scheme (Instituto Superior Técnico Catalogue)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090924222039/http://istpress.ist.utl.pt/lscheme.htm |date=2009-09-24 }}
* The Chronicle of the Fountain Pen, Schiffer Publishing Ltd., 2007 (Martins, J. P.; Leite, Luiz, Gagean, António) {{cite web|url= http://www.schifferbooks.com/the-chronicle-of-the-fountain-pen-stories-within-a-story-3302.html|title= The Chronicle of the Fountain Pen}}
* Meerschaum Pipes@eBay (1999-2010), www.blurb.com, 2010 (Martins J. P. (ed.)) {{cite web|url= http://www.blurb.com/books/1545260-meerschaum-pipes-ebay-1999-2010|title= Meerschaum Pipes@eBay (1999-2010)}}
* Pipes@eBay (1999-2010), www.blurb.com, 2010 (Martins J. P.) {{cite web|url= http://www.blurb.com/books/1589745-pipes-ebay-1999-2010|title= Pipes@eBay (1999-2010)}}
* Parker: An Illustrated History, www.blurb.com, 2011 (Martins J. P., Leite L. e Gagean A.) {{cite web|url= http://www.blurb.com/books/2472051-parker-an-illustrated-history-part-1|title= Parker: An Illustrated History}}
* Sheaffer: An Illustrated History, www.blurb.com, 2011 (Martins J. P., Leite L. e Gagean A.) {{cite web|url= http://www.blurb.com/books/2472070-sheaffer-an-illustrated-history|title= Sheaffer: An Illustrated History}}
* Lógica e Raciocínio, Cadernos de Lógica e Computação Volume 6, College Publications, 2014,(Martins J.P.) {{cite web|url= http://www.collegepublications.co.uk/clc/?00006|title= Lógica e Raciocínio, Cadernos de Lógica e Computação Volume 6}}
* Programação em PYTHON: Introdução à Programação Utilizando Múltiplos Paradigmas, IST Press, 2015 (Martins J. P.) {{cite web|url= http://istpress.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/node/413|title= Programação em PYTHON: Introdução à Programação Utilizando Múltiplos Paradigmas}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Martins, Joao Pavao}} [[Category:Artificial intelligence researchers]] [[Category:Portuguese businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Instituto Superior Técnico alumni]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.text:
{{No footnotes|article|date=April 2009}}[[Image:Kinga Rusin 2015.jpg|thumb|Kinga Rusin, 2015]]
'''Kinga Rusin''' (born March 9, 1971) is a popular Polish TV presenter.
She was born in [[Warsaw]]. She pursued Italian studies at [[Warsaw University]], but never graduated. She began her career working for [[Telewizja Polska|TVP]] (Polish National Television) as a program announcer. She left Poland in 1994 with her husband, [[Tomasz Lis]], and worked as a women's magazines correspondent in the United States of America.
She returned to Poland with her husband in 1997 and began working for [[TVN (Poland)|TVN]], where she was the presenter of ''Wizjer''.
Since 2005, she has been hosting popular Polish morning show, ''[[Dzień Dobry TVN]]'', and the Polish version of ''[[So You Think You Can Dance (U.S. TV series)|So You Think You Can Dance]]'', ''Po prostu tańcz''. In 2011 she became a judge for So you Think You Can Dance
In 2006, she came first in a popular celebrity dancing show, during the fourth season of ''Taniec z gwiazdami'' (the Polish version of [[Dancing With The Stars]]). She danced with [[Stefano Terrazino]]. Moreover, she won a special episode of this show called ''Dancing with the Stars - the most beautiful dances'' (''Taniec z gwiazdami – najpiękniejsze tańce'').
She is the owner of the company ''Idea Media Wende Rusin''.
==Family== She married [[Tomasz Lis]] in June 1994. They have two daughters: Pola and Iga. They divorced on June 27, 2006.
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070705184739/http://www.ideamedia.pl/index_en.htm Idea Media Wende Rusin] * [http://kinga4fans.prv.pl Fansite of Kinga Rusin] * [http://www.kingarusin.pl Official Website]
{{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Dancing with the Stars (Polish TV series)]] winner | before=Rafał Mroczek & Aneta Piotrowska | years=Season 4 (Autumn 2006 with Stefano Terrazino) | after= Krzysztof Tyniec & Kamila Kajak |end box }} {{s-end}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rusin, Kinga}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Taniec z gwiazdami|Rusin]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Writers from Warsaw]] [[Category:Polish businesspeople]] [[Category:Polish television personalities]] [[Category:You Can Dance: Po prostu tańcz!|Rusin]] [[Category:Polish women in business]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Laurits Christian Meulengracht |image = Laurits (Lars) Christian Meulengracht.jpg |image_size = 140 |caption = Laurits Christian Meulengracht c. 1890 |nationality = [[Denmark|Danish]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1837|2|14|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Aarhus]], Denmark |death_date = {{death date and age|1903|5|9|1837|2|14|df=y}} |death_place = [[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]] }} '''Laurits Christian Meulengracht''' or '''Laurits Christopher Meulengracht''' (14 February 1837 - 9 April 1903) was a [[Denmark|Danish]] businessman and [[brewer]] who became one of the wealthiest men in Denmark in the 19th century. He received the [[Order of the Dannebrog]] and [[Order of the Dannebrog|Knight of the Dannebrog]].<ref name="ACA">{{cite web |url=http://aarhuswiki.dk/wiki/Lars_Christian_Meulengracht_(1837-1903) |title=Lars Christian Meulengracht (1837-1903) |publisher=Aarhus City Archives |language=Danish |accessdate=12 September 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6kTKzHJ3h?url=http://aarhuswiki.dk/wiki/Lars_Christian_Meulengracht_(1837-1903) |archive-date=12 September 2016 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="Lund">{{cite web |url=http://www.lundskov.dk/menu/aarhusperson.htm |title=Meulengracht slægten |publisher=Lundskov |language=Danish |accessdate=12 September 2016 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130701052124/http://www.lundskov.dk/menu/aarhusperson.htm |archive-date=1 July 2013 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
His father Lars Christian Meulengracht died 6 months before he was born so he grew up in his grandfather [[Harboe Meulengracht]]'s house. 15 years old he started an internship in the store of Malthe Conrad Lottrup, a local businessman who among other things owned a sizable brewery. In 1858 he was sent to [[Copenhagen]] to study trade further and in 1862 he started a successful business in [[London]]. However, by 1870 his former mentor Malthe Conrad Lottrup had fallen ill and called Meulengracht home to take over management of Lottrup's [[Ceres Brewery]].<ref name="DSD">{{cite web|url=http://denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/H%C3%A5ndv%C3%A6rk/Brygger/L._Chr._Meulengracht |title=L. Chr. Meulengracht |publisher=[[Gyldendal]]'s Encyclopedia ''Den Store Danske'' |language=Danish |accessdate=12 September 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6kTL0XR6f?url=http://denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/H%C3%A5ndv%C3%A6rk/Brygger/L._Chr._Meulengracht |archive-date=12 September 2016 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="Grav">{{cite web|url=http://www.gravsted.dk/person.php?navn=lcmeulengracht |title=Laurits Chr. Meulengracht |publisher=Gravsted |language=Danish |accessdate=12 September 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6kTL2RWv6?url=http://www.gravsted.dk/person.php?navn=lcmeulengracht |archive-date=12 September 2016 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
Meulengracht took over the brewery and managed it through a lifetime. Initially he rationalized and bought new technology in the form of an [[steam engine]]. In the years 1872-88 a large expansion program was undertaken that eventually made Ceres the largest brewery in [[Jutland]] and Meulengracht one of the wealthiest people in Aarhus. Tax records show he paid more in taxes than even contemporary [[Otto Mønsted]] and [[Hans Broge]]. Meulengracht eventually moved into a new home on the Ceres-complex which eventually became a social focal point for the local upper class. As an employer he was known for his ability to make opposing groups work together and privately Meulengracht was active in charity and advocacy work. In 1876 he was elected to the city council and held his seat for 14 years, working in numerous committees particularly on public works and infrastructure. Meulengracht was also one of the forces behind the establishment [[Aarhus Theatre]] and he sat on the first board after it was opened.<ref name="ACA"/><ref name="DSD"/>
Laurits Meulengracht died 9 April 1903, after lengthy illness and during a healing trip to [[Monte Carlo]]. He was buried on [[Nordre Cemetery]] in Aarhus.
== Honors == Meulengracht had the official honorary title of ''etatsråd'' and he received the [[Order of the Dannebrog]] and [[Order of the Dannebrog|Knight of the Dannebrog]].<ref name="DSD"/>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Meulengracht, Laurits Christian}} [[Category:People from Aarhus]] [[Category:Danish businesspeople]] [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1903 deaths]] [[Category:Burials at Nordre Cemetery]] [[Category:Order of the Dannebrog]] [[Category:Knights of the Order of the Dannebrog]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Chinese name|[[Lin (surname)|Lin]]}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Lin Yu-lin | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1936|10|6|df=y}} | birth_place = Shinshō, [[Taihoku Prefecture]], [[Taiwan under Japanese rule|Japanese Taiwan]]
(now [[New Taipei City]], Taiwan) | death_date = {{death date and age|2018|6|9|1936|10|6|df=y}} | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Taiwanese | occupation = real estate developer | salary = | networth = US$5.7 billion (January 2015){{cite web|title=Lin Yu-Lin|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/lin-yu-lin/|website=Forbes|accessdate=5 January 2015}} | spouse = | parents = | children = 7 | relatives = [[Lin Rong-San]] (brother) | website = }} '''Lin Yu-lin''' ({{zh|t=林堉璘}}; 6 October 1936 – 9 June 2018) was a [[Taiwan]]ese billionaire real estate developer, brother of fellow billionaire and politician [[Lin Rong-San]]. ==Biography== Lin Yu-lin was born in 1936.https://tw.news.appledaily.com/headline/daily/20180610/38039913/ He was a real estate mogul, owner of the commercial property [[Hung Tai Center]], and a major investor in the construction companies Hung Sheng Construction, Cooperative Construction and Hung Tai Asset Management. He was also a key shareholder in [[En Tie Commercial Bank]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2011/87/taiwan-billionaires-11_Lin-Yu-Lin_ASVN.html|title=#8 Lin Yu-Lin|website=Forbes}} He owned the office and retail complexes Exchange Square I and II in Taipei. According to [[Forbes]], Lin had a net worth of $5.7 billion in January 2015. He was married with seven children and lived in [[Taipei]]. He died on 9 June 2018 at the age of 81.{{Cite news|url=https://tw.news.yahoo.com/%E5%8F%B0%E7%81%A3%E5%9C%B0%E7%8E%8B-%E5%AE%8F%E6%B3%B0%E5%89%B5%E8%BE%A6%E4%BA%BA%E6%9E%97%E5%A0%89%E7%92%9883%E6%AD%B2%E9%81%8E%E4%B8%96-%E6%9B%BE%E6%8D%90%E5%8D%83%E5%84%84%E5%85%AC%E7%9B%8A%E4%BF%A1%E8%A8%97-134748568.html|title=台灣地王、宏泰創辦人林堉璘83歲過世 曾捐千億公益信託|last=Shen|first=Chaoqun|date=2018-06-09|work=Yahoo Taiwan|access-date=2018-06-09|language=zh-Hant-TW}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.yu-lin.com.tw/ Official website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lin, Yu-Lin}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Taiwanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Taiwanese billionaires]] [[Category:Taiwanese people of Hoklo descent]] [[Category:People from New Taipei]] {{Taiwan-business-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{for|a list of stations sorted alphabetically by city of license|List of ABC television affiliates (table)}} The '''[[American Broadcasting Company]] (ABC)''' is an [[United States|American]] [[terrestrial television|broadcast television]] [[television network]] owned by the [[Disney Media Networks]] subsidiary of [[The Walt Disney Company]], which originated in 1927 as the [[Blue Network|NBC Blue]] [[radio network]], and five years after its 1942 divorce from [[NBC]] and purchase by [[Edward J. Noble]] (adopting its current name the following year), expanded into television in April 1948. {{As of|March 2015}}, the network currently has eight [[owned-and-operated station]]s, and current [[network affiliate|affiliation agreements]] with 238 other television stations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stations for Network - ABC|url=http://www.rabbitears.info/search.php?request=network_search&network=ABC|work=[[RabbitEars]]|accessdate=March 20, 2015}}</ref>
This article is a listing of current ABC affiliates in the [[continental United States]] and U.S. possessions (including [[digital subchannel|subchannel]] affiliates, [[Broadcast relay station#Satellite stations|satellite stations]] and select [[low-power broadcasting|low-power]] [[Broadcast relay station#Broadcast translators|translators]]), arranged alphabetically by state, and based on the station's [[city of license]], and followed in parentheses by the [[media market|Designated Market Area]] if it differs from the city of license. There are links to and articles on each of the stations, describing their histories, local programming and technical information, such as broadcast frequencies.
The station's advertised channel number follows the call letters. In most cases, this is their [[virtual channel]] ([[Program and System Information Protocol|PSIP]]) number.
Stations listed in '''boldface''' are owned and operated by ABC through its subsidiary [[ABC Owned Television Stations]].
{{Horizontal TOC|nonum=y|limit=3}}
==United States and Territories== ===Alabama=== * [[Anniston, Alabama|Anniston]] – [[WGWW|WGWW-DT2]] 40.2 (simulcast of WBMA-LD) * [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]] – [[WBMA-LD]] 58 / [[WABM|WABM-DT2]] 68.2 * [[Dothan, Alabama|Dothan]] – [[WDHN]] 18 * [[Huntsville, Alabama|Huntsville]] – [[WAAY-TV]] 31 * [[Montgomery, Alabama|Montgomery]] – [[WNCF]] 32 * [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama|Tuscaloosa]] – [[WDBB|WDBB-DT2]] 17.2 (satellite of WBMA-LD)
===Alaska=== Some ABC programming is broadcast on the [[Alaska Rural Communications Service]] (ARCS). * [[Anchorage, Alaska|Anchorage]] – [[KYUR]] 13 * [[Fairbanks, Alaska|Fairbanks]] – [[KATN]] 2 * [[Juneau, Alaska|Juneau]] – [[KJUD]] 8
===Arizona=== * [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] – [[KNXV-TV]] 15 * [[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson]] – [[KGUN-TV]] 9 *[[Yuma, Arizona|Yuma-El Centro]] - [[KECY-TV]] 5
===Arkansas=== * [[Fayetteville, Arkansas|Fayetteville]] – KHOG-TV 29 (satellite of KHBS) * [[Fort Smith, Arkansas|Fort Smith]] – [[KHBS]] 40 * [[Jonesboro, Arkansas|Jonesboro]] – [[KAIT]] 8 * [[Little Rock, Arkansas|Little Rock]] – [[KATV]] 7
===California=== * [[Arcata, California|Arcata]] ([[Eureka, California|Eureka]]) – [[KAEF-TV]] 23 * [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]] – [[KERO-TV]] 23 * [[El Centro, California|El Centro]] – [[KECY-TV|KECY-DT2]] 9.2 * [[Fresno, California|Fresno]] – '''[[KFSN-TV]] 30''' * [[Los Angeles]] – '''[[KABC-TV]] 7''' * [[Palm Springs, California|Palm Springs]] – [[KESQ-TV]] 42 * [[Redding, California|Redding]] – [[KRCR-TV]] 7 * [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]] – [[KXTV]] 10 * [[Salinas, California|Salinas]] – [[KSBW-DT2]] 8.2 * [[San Diego]] – [[KGTV]] 10 * [[San Francisco]] – '''[[KGO-TV]] 7''' * [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]] – [[KEYT-TV]] 3
===Colorado=== * [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]] – [[KRDO-TV]] 13 * [[Denver]] – [[KMGH-TV]] 7 * [[Grand Junction, Colorado|Grand Junction]] – [[KJCT-LP]] 8
===Connecticut=== * [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven]] – [[WTNH-TV]] 8

revision.comment: /* References */ scottish
revision.text:
Sir '''Louis Stewart Gumley''' LLD (1870 –1941) was a Scottish property agent who founded the firm '''Gumleys''' and who served as [[Lord Provost of Edinburgh]] from 1935 to 1938. Gumleys merged in 1989 to become '''Speirs Gumley'''.<ref>The Sunday Herald (newspaper) 30 May 2016</ref>
==Life==
He was born in [[Dublin]] in Ireland on 7 May 1870 the son of Thomas Franc Sadler Gumley and his wife Wilhelmina Moffat.<ref>https://www.bayanne.info/Shetland/familygroup.php?familyID=F325918&tree=ID1</ref>
He moved to [[Edinburgh]] around 1890 with his mother, following the death of his father, and they lived in a flat at 11 Howe Street.<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1890-91</ref>
He founded Gumleys in 1898 at 84 [[Leith Walk]].<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1899-1900</ref>
In 1910 he was running a property business at 89 [[Leith Walk]] and living at 3 Dundas Street in [[New Town, Edinburgh|Edinburgh's Second New Town]].<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1910-11</ref>
He died on 30 September 1941 at [[Bowness-on-Windermere]] in the [[Lake District]] but was returned to [[Edinburgh]] for burial in [[Warriston Cemetery]] in the north of the city. The grave lies at the west end of the upper section close to the main entrance path.
==Artistic Recognition==
His portrait by [[Stanley Cursiter]] was painted in 1937 and is held by [[City of Edinburgh Council]].
==Recognition==
He was knighted by King [[George V]] during his period as Lord Provost.
==Family== In 1901 he married Catherine Isabella Horne Lindsay (1876-1951).
His sons included Charles Stewart Gumley [[Writer to the Signet|WS]] (1908-1977) and Ronald Guthrie Tait Gumley (1912-1998).
==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gumley, Louis Stewart}}
[[Category:1870 births]] [[Category:1941 deaths]] [[Category:People from County Dublin]] [[Category:Lord Provosts of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]]
{{Scotland-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox President | name = Mehdi Karroubi | image = Mehdi Karroubi in Isfahan - 15 May 2009 (cropped).jpg | imagesize = 240px | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1937|09|26|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Aligudarz]], [[Lorestan Province]], [[Iran]] | order = [[List of Speakers of the Parliament of Iran|19th Speaker of the Parliament of Iran]] | deputy = [[Behzad Nabavi]]
[[Mohammad-Reza Khatami]] | term_start = 28 May 2000 | term_end = 28 May 2004 | predecessor = [[Ali Akbar Nategh Nouri]] | successor = [[Gholam-Ali Haddad-Adel]] | term_start2 = 3 August 1989 | term_end2 = 3 May 1992 | predecessor2 = [[Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]] | successor2 = [[Ali Akbar Nategh-Nouri]] | 2blankname2 = Deputy | 2namedata2 = Hossein Hashemian | order3 = [[List of Speakers of the Parliament of Iran|First Deputy of the Parliament of Iran]] | term_start3 = 28 June 1988 | term_end3 = 3 August 1989 | predecessor3 = [[Mohammad Yazdi]] | successor3 = Hossein Hashemian | term_start4 = 15 June 1986 | term_end4 = 14 June 1987 | predecessor4 = [[Mohammad Yazdi]] | successor4 = [[Mohammad Yazdi]] | order5 = [[Parliament of Iran|Member of Parliament of Iran]] | term_start5 = 28 May 2000 | termend5 = 28 May 2004 | constituency5 = [[Tehran, Rey, Shemiranat and Eslamshahr (electoral district)|Tehran, Rey, Shemiranat and Eslamshahr]] | majority5 = 892,640 (30.45%) | term_start6 = 28 May 1984 | term_end6 = 28 May 1992 | constituency6 = [[Tehran, Rey, Shemiranat and Eslamshahr (electoral district)|Tehran, Rey, Shemiranat and Eslamshahr]] | majority6 = 965,484 (61.4%; 3rd term), 1,443,270 (62.5%; 2nd term) | term_start7 = 28 May 1980 | term_end7 = 28 May 1984 | constituency7 = [[Aligoudarz (electoral district)|Aligoudarz]] | majority7 = 49,097 (92.9%) | successor7 = Mohammad-Reza Hashemi | party = {{plainlist| * [[The Green Path of Hope]] {{small|(2009–present)}} * [[National Trust Party (Iran)|National Trust Party]] {{small|(2005–present)}} * [[Association of Combatant Clerics]] {{small|(1988–2005)}} * [[Islamic Republican Party]] {{small|(1979–1987)}} * [[Combatant Clergy Association]] {{small|(1978–1988)}} }} | otherparty = | alma_mater = [[University of Tehran]] | spouse = [[Fatemeh Karroubi]] {{small|(m. 1962)}}{{cite news|first=Aresu|last=Eqbali|title=Iranian women need more rights: candidate's wife|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jDD9Q1xNs5VIqwgzYINkyU2y5Upg|work=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|publisher=[[Google News]]|date=29 May 2009|accessdate=25 June 2009}} | children = 4 | website = [http://sahamnews.org/ Official website] }} '''Mehdi Karroubi''' ({{lang-fa|مهدی کروبی|Mehdī Karrūbĩ}}, born 26 September 1937) is an [[Iran]]ian [[Shia]] cleric and [[Iranian reform movement|reformist]] [[politician]] leading the [[National Trust Party (Iran)|National Trust Party]]. He was the speaker of the [[Majlis of Iran|parliament]] from 1989 to 1992 and 2000 to 2004, and a presidential candidate in the [[Iranian presidential election, 2005|2005]] and [[Iranian presidential election, 2009|2009 presidential elections]]. Following [[2009–2010 Iranian election protests]], Karroubi was put under [[house arrest]] in February 2011 – reportedly ordered by the [[Supreme Leader of Iran]] – without officially being charged, although he is accused of being a "seditionist" and "traitor". As of 2018, he is still confined to his house. He has been described as a "moderate" with a "mostly rural" base of support.[[#refNewYorker|New Yorker, 13 April 2009]] Karroubi considers himself a pragmatic reformist and now is one of the leaders of the [[Iranian Green Movement]].{{cite news|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/printArticle.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=357975&version=1&template_id=37&parent_id=17|title=Mousavi and Karoubi set stage for new showdown|newspaper=Gulf Times |date=27 April 2010|accessdate=30 August 2010}} He is a founding member and former secretary-general of the [[Association of Combatant Clerics]] party. Karroubi is a critic of the [[Guardian Council]] and Iran's Judicial System. By appointment of the [[Supreme Leader]], he was a member of the [[Expediency Discernment Council]] and an adviser, posts he held until resigning from all his posts on 15 June 2005 after the first round of the 2005 presidential election. ==Early life, education, and career== Mehdi Karroubi is born on 26 September 1937 into a [[Shia]] clerical family in [[Aligudarz]], a city in the western part of [[Lorestan province]]. He has a brother, Hassan. Karroubi studied theology and Islamic studies at seminaries in [[Qom]] and Tehran. He studied under notable figures such as [[Hossein-Ali Montazeri]] and [[Ruhollah Khomeini]]. Karroubi was promoted to [[Mujtahid]] on the recommendation of the [[Grand Ayatollah]] [[Yousef Sanei]] and others. He also studied [[theology]] and [[law]] at [[Tehran University]].{{cite web |url=http://www.karroubi.ir/biography.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090522003624/http://www.karroubi.ir/biography.html |archivedate=22 May 2009 |df=dmy-all }} In 1962, he became a [[private law|lawyer in economy]], dealing with the investments of prominent businessmen in [[Iran]]. Karroubi was imprisoned several times by the government of the [[Pahlavi dynasty|Shah of Iran]], [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]], during the 1970s, including a stint at the [[Qasr Prison]] in [[Tehran]]. His wife, Fatemeh, later recalled that she took their second son, Taghi, to meet his father at Qasr Prison for the first time when he was six months old. In 1978, Karroubi retired from [[law]] in order to commit to politics. In 1979, he joined the [[Iranian Revolution]]. Karroubi was the head of the Imam Khomeini Relief Committee and the Martyr's Foundation shortly after Iranian revolution.[[#refIranFocus|iranfocus.com, 14 June 2005]] In 1988, Karroubi re-entered business after 10 years of emphasis on politics. With eighteen years of experience as a [[solicitor]] beforehand, Karroubi began trading and investing himself. ==Political positions== ===Domestic policies=== During his first term as speaker of Parliament, Karroubi was among the ''maktabi'' or "radical" faction of the majlis who contested the policies of President [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]]. While Rafsanjani favored foreign investment and market reforms, Karroubi and others "sought to promote mass political participation and maintain state control of the economy". In fall of 1989 several radical clerics founded the Association of Combatant Clerics of Tehran, which Karroubi headed. Karroubi eventually left this association in 2005 and founded his own party, ''Etemad-e-Melli''.[[#refBrumberg|Brumberg, p. 162]] His wife, Fatemeh, served as his social affairs advisors when he served as the chairman of the Majlis of Iran from 2000 until 2004. Among politicians in the Islamic Republic, he has been one of the leading supporters of civil rights for citizens. Karroubi was long an advocate of women's rights and the presence of women in all social activities. He has been supportive of women taking leadership roles within their political groups.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/classic/detail.aspx?id=95082§ionid=3510302|title=No Operation|work=PressTV|accessdate=30 August 2010}} Mehdi Karroubi, an ethnic [[Lurs|Lur]], supports an approach where all people regardless of their gender, religion, or ethnicity can feel that they are part of Iranian government. He was outspoken in supporting the rights of religious and ethnic minorities. He visited churches, synagogues and [[Zoroastrian]] temples during his time as speaker of Parliament. Karroubi is a critic of the [[Guardian Council]] and on numerous occasions wrote letters to the council expressing his concerns. He criticized the nature of the Guardian Council's supervision over the elections, saying in 2009 "I have opposed the notion of 'approbation supervision' power since it was introduced 20 years ago … But, today the problem goes beyond 'approbation supervision'. What goes on today is not 'supervision' at all. Guardian Council inspectors hold absolute authority and control over the elections". ===Foreign policies=== Karroubi and the National Trust Party support the idea of dialogue with the [[United States]] aiming at resolving long standing conflicts. Early after the election of [[Barack Obama]] as US president, Karroubi stated that the changes from the United States have been positive. "An important step has been taken…. I will take steps forward in this relation in accordance with national interests and national pride", he said. Karroubi has been a critic of President Ahmadinejad's foreign policy and his infamous remarks about the Holocaust. Karroubi said: "The Holocaust is an event which did take place."{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/features/article_1477152.php/Mehdi_Karroubi_Underdog_but_not_to_be_underestimated__Feature|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130216113634/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/features/article_1477152.php/Mehdi_Karroubi_Underdog_but_not_to_be_underestimated__Feature|dead-url=yes|archive-date=16 February 2013|title=Mehdi Karroubi: Underdog but not to be underestimated (Feature)|work=Monsters and Critics|date=14 May 2009|accessdate=30 August 2010}} He believes that the president's remarks cost Iran a great deal.{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/08/oct/1112.html|title=Iranian Reformist Mehdi Karoubi to Run in 2009 Presidential Race |work=Payvand|date=22 November 2006|accessdate=30 August 2010}} ==Presidential campaigns== ===2005 presidential campaign=== Karroubi was among the [[Iranian reformists|reformist]] candidates in the [[Iranian presidential election, 2005|presidential election of 2005]], where he finished third in the vote count, closely following the front runners, ex-president [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]] and Tehran mayor [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]]. As neither gathered a majority of the vote, a run-off election was held on 24 June 2005, and won by Ahmadinejad. After the announcement of the election results, Karroubi alleged that a network of [[mosque]]s, the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]], and Basij militia forces had been illegally used to generate and mobilize support for Ahmadinejad. He then explicitly alleged that [[Mojtaba Khamenei]], a son of the [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Supreme Leader]] [[Ayatollah Khamenei]], was among the conspirators. Ayatollah Khamenei wrote to Karroubi, characterizing these allegations as "below his dignity" and warning that they would "result in a crisis" in [[Iran]], which he would not allow. Karroubi responded in an open letter, resigning from all his political posts, including that as adviser to the Supreme Leader and as a member of [[Expediency Discernment Council]], both of which he had been appointed to by Khamenei. The day after, on 20 June, distribution of the reformist morning newspapers ''[[Eqbal]]'', ''[[Hayat-e No]]'', ''[[Aftab-e Yazd]]'', and ''[[Etemad]]'' were stopped by the prosecutor-general of Tehran, [[Saeed Mortazavi]], for publishing Karroubi's letter, with ''Eqbal'' being completely banned from publication.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/story/2005/06/050619_mf_hashemi_statement.shtml Election Statement] BBC Persian. It was claimed that Karroubi was subject to house arrest because of his letter. [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]], who ranked first in the first round, also pointed to organized and unjust interventions, alleged manipulation of the vote, and supported Karroubi's complaint.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/story/2005/06/050619_mf_hashemi_statement.shtml|title=Hashemi Rafsanjani's Statement|publisher=BBC|language=Persian}} ===2009 presidential election=== Immediately after the 2005 presidential election Karroubi founded [[National Trust Party (Iran)|Etemad-e Melli Party]], and along with it ''Etemad-e Melli'' newspaper. In the 2009 election, he ran as the head of his party. However, many non-party figures also endorsed him. Karroubi was described as "the best-organized" among the main candidates. He has his own party, his own newspaper and has always followed a clear political stance. He claimed to be the first candidate to announce his candidacy for the presidency. During the last months before the election, he refused a call for him to withdraw in the support of [[Mohammad Khatami]] or later [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]]. After Khatami withdrew from the race in March, Karroubi said "I have neither signed contracts with anyone nor have been promised anything. Khatami withdrew his candidacy by virtue of his personal decision. In my meeting with Mousavi I persuaded him to join the fray."{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=91185§ionid=351020101|title=Karroubi rejects Khatami's request?|work=Press TV|date=12 April 2009|accessdate=21 June 2009}} Later, both Mousavi and Karroubi stated that a union among reformists would only help Ahamadinejad's reelection, claiming that reformists needed a massive turn out in order to win and that more candidates would advance their interests. Karroubi publicized his policies by publishing four electoral declarations. According to a paper handed to his supporters during the campaign his main policies are: # Returning to the planned-based system of governing and using the elite and experts in decision making process # Organizing financial policies and increasing the effect of national budget # Protecting human rights and people's privacy # Improving women's social status # Nationalizing oil profits # Supporting NGOs # Supporting the right of religious or tribal minorities # Supporting the domination of law and opposing and criticizing illegal behavior # Supporting the press and free access to the information and internet In a 2009 interview with the [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]], Karroubi also promised to expand women's rights if elected president of Iran. Among the reforms which he planned to introduce were elimination of [[Guidance Patrol|Iran's morality police street patrols]], which force an Islamic [[dress code]] on Iranian women. He questioned mandatory Islamic dress code and proposed that Hijab needs to be optional.{{cite web|url=http://www.tabnak.ir/fa/pages/?cid=56059|title=آسیب شناسی انتخابات دهم ریاست جمهوری|work=Tabnak|accessdate=30 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726132137/http://www.tabnak.ir/fa/pages/?cid=56059|archivedate=26 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} His foremost economic program is for broad public ownership of the national oil and gas companies. According to this plan, adopted from the pro-market economist [[Massoud Nilli]],{{citation|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/tehranbureau/2009/06/irans-ralph-nader.html|title=The Curious Case of Mehdi Karroubi: Iran's Ralph Nader?|date=3 June 2009|access-date=16 August 2017|work=Tehran Bureau|publisher=PBS}} company stock and profits would be shared among Iranians above 18 years of age, without the right to sell. He has predicted that this will add 70000 Tomans a month to every Iranian's income. His campaign slogan was "Change for Iran", a word visible on his banners and other advertisements. Former Tehran mayor [[Gholamhossein Karbaschi]] was among the first to endorse him, and was Karroubi's campaign manager. Karroubi has promised to appoint him vice president if elected. Karroubi also gained endorsements from journalist [[Abbas Abdi]], now his political advisor, and [[Jamileh Kadivar]], former member of the parliament and his advisor on women's issues. Other notable supporters include: [[Ata'ollah Mohajerani]], historian, politician, journalist, and author and former culture minister during Khatami's presidency; [[Mohammad-Ali Abtahi]], President Khatami's chief of staff, then his Vice President for Legal and Parliamentary Affairs, and finally his advisor; [[Mohammad-Ali Najafi]], Iranian politician and university professor and former minister of education; [[Emadeddin Baghi]], the founder and head of the [[Committee for the Defense of Prisoners' Rights]] and the Society of Right to Life Guardians, and winner of the [[Martin Ennals Award for Human Rights Defenders]]; [[Abdolkarim Soroush]], philosopher and professor. Mehdi Karroubi widely campaigned with his wife, [[Fatemeh Karroubi]], during the campaign, which had previously been an unusual for a politician and his wife in Iran. Fatemeh Karroubi additionally served as the head of her husband's campaign in [[Tehran province]] and made separate speeches in support of her husband's candidacy. Karroubi's son, Taghi Karroubi, worked as one of his [[campaign manager]]s. ==Post-election activity== On 9 August 2009, in a letter to the Chairman of the Expediency Discernment Council of Iran, Karroubi demanded investigation of Iranian prisons for possible tortures and in particular sexual harassment of men and women.[http://www.economist.com/world/mideast-africa/displaystory.cfm?story_id=14222321 Iran and human rights: The crackdown] ''Economist'' On 19 August, he wrote to parliament speaker Ali Larijani, asking to meet with him, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, judiciary chief Ayatollah Sadeq Larijani, former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani and the state prosecutor to "personally present my documents and evidence over the cases of sexual abuse in some prisons specially [[Kahrizak detention center]]."{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/Iran/idUSDAH93169320090819|title=Iran reformer says he wants to present rape evidence|work=Reuters|date=19 August 2009|accessdate=19 August 2009}} [[Ali Larijani]] and [[Sadeq Larijani]] both officially rejected his claims and [[Ali Khamenei]]'s representatives and vice chairman of National Security Commission of the parliament demanded Karroubi's arrest.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ixeFBxfLzaSjs8Mb8cuFmtPOT6-wD9ALTVP00 dead link]{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} ===Attacks=== On 8 January 2010, Karroubi's son, Hussein Karroubi reported on Karroubi's Website, Saham News, that shots had been fired at his armored car by pro-government demonstrators in [[Qazvin]]. Demonstrators also threw "bricks and rocks" at the flat where he was staying. The ''[[New York Times]]'' newspaper reported that he "has been pushed and shoved" and had a shoe thrown "at him — a grave insult in Iran" — since the election. "But this was the first time someone shot at him."[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/09/world/middleeast/09iran.html Shots Fired at Iran Opposition Leader’s Car, Son Says] ''The New York Times'' Nazila Fathi, 8 January 2010 On 2 September 2010, 20 members of the [[Basij]] militia broke into Karroubi's apartment building. They shot at the building, set small fires in the courtyard, the lobby, vandalized parts of the building, cut water pipes to the apartment and tried to cut power on the street. This was the fourth consecutive night that Karroubi's apartment has come under attack. Karroubi's son, Mohammad Taghi Karroubi, said he heard several of the men say they were there to kill his father. Several of Karroubi's security team were injured when pleading with the gathering to stay outside the building to no avail. The head of a security team protecting Karroubi was in a coma after being beaten, as he tried to talk with a group of attackers.[http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/meast/09/02/iran.karoubi/index.html#fbid=bWTYV6M6pLq&wom=false Iranian opposition leader comes under attack, website says] ''CNN'' ===House arrest=== In the wake of the [[2010–2011 Tunisian revolution|Tunisian]] and [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|Egyptian revolutions]], Green movement leaders in Iran called for demonstrations on 14 February 2011. The government responded by placing leaders of the movement under [[house arrest]] and on 14 February Iranian state TV broadcast images of "some 50 conservative MPs marching through parliament's main hall" chanting "Death to Mousavi, death to Karroubi".[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12462491 Iran unrest: MPs call for death of Mousavi and Karroubi], ''BBC'', 15 February 2011 A statement issued by conservative Iranian parliamentarians carried by the official [[Islamic Republic News Agency]] said: "Mehdi Karroubi and Mir Hossein Mousavi are corrupts on earth and should be tried." "Corrupt on earth" ([[Mofsed-e-filarz]]) is a capital crime sometimes levied against political dissidents in the Islamic Republic of Iran. According to reports, Karroubi, fellow Iranian opposition leader [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]], and their wives [[Fatemeh Karroubi]] and [[Zahra Rahnavard]], were taken from their homes by security forces to [[Heshmatiyeh Prison]] in Tehran in February 2011.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12599837 Iran: Mir Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi 'arrested'], ''BBC News'' === Hunger strike === On 16 August 2017, Karroubi started a [[hunger strike]] in protest to his [[house arrest]] situation, calling for an [[Public trial|open trial]] and demanding security agents to leave his house.{{citation|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-rights-karroubi-idUSKCN1AW1O8?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews|title=Iran's detained opposition leader Karroubi starts hunger strike|work=Reuters|author=Bozorgmehr Sharafedin|editor=Jeremy Gaunt|date=16 August 2017|access-date=16 August 2017}} The 79-year-old politician who underwent a heart surgery days earlier was taken to hospital after less than 24 hours and resumed eating after the government agreed to remove intelligence agents from his home. His demand for trial seems not close to be granted.{{citation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/18/iran-reformist-leader-mehdi-karroubi-ends-hunger-strike|title=Iran reformist leader Mehdi Karroubi ends hunger strike|work=The Guardian|date=18 August 2017|access-date=20 August 2017|via=Agence France-Presse}} ==Personal life== Karroubi has been married to [[Fatemeh Karroubi]], the daughter of an Aligoudarz [[mercantile]] family, since she was 14. ==References== {{clear}} {{Reflist|30em}} ;Sources * {{cite web|url=http://www.aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=3&id=8613|title=Mehdi Karroubi: Iran’s Most Prominent Reformist Speaks|ref=refAawsat}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/04/13/090413fa_fact_anderson?printable=true|title=Can Iran Change? High stakes in Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s reelection campaign. |author=Jon Lee Anderson|date=13 April 2009|publisher=[[The New Yorker|New Yorker]]|ref=refNewYorker}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.iranfocus.com/en/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2392|title=Iran elections candidates: Mehdi Karroubi|publisher=Iran Focus|date=14 June 2005|accessdate=21 June 2009|ref=refIranFocus}} * {{cite book|author=Brumberg, Daniel|title=Reinventing Khomeini: The Struggle for Reform in Iran|publisher= University of Chicago Press |year=2001|page=162|ref=refBrumberg}} * {{cite journal|publisher=Iran Human Rights Documentation Center|title=Violent Aftermath: The 2009 Election and Suppression of Dissent in Iran|date=February 2010|location=New Haven, CT|url=http://www.iranhrdc.org/httpdocs/English/pdfs/Reports/Violent%20Aftermath.pdf|page=6}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Mehdi Karroubi}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090404114022/http://karroubi.ir/ Official Personal Website] {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-new|reason=Party established}} {{s-ttl|title= General Secretary of [[Association of Combatant Clerics]]|years=1988–2005}} {{s-aft|after=[[Mohammad Mousavi Khoeiniha]]}} |- {{s-new|reason=Party established}} {{s-ttl|title= General Secretary of [[National Trust Party (Iran)|National Trust Party]]|years=2005–present|alongside=[[Rasoul Montajabnia]] {{small|(Acting: 2011–2018)}}
[[Elias Hazrati]] {{small|(Acting: 2018–)}}}} {{s-inc}} |- {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Speaker of [[Parliament of Iran]]|years=1989–1992}} {{s-aft|after=[[Ali Akbar Nategh Nouri]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Ali Akbar Nategh Nouri]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Speaker of [[Parliament of Iran]]|years=2000–2004}} {{s-aft|after=[[Gholam Ali Haddad-Adel]]}} {{s-end}} {{Chairmen of the Majlis of Iran}} {{Green Movement}} {{Iranian presidential election, 2009 footer}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Karroubi, Mehdi}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:Association of Combatant Clerics politicians]] [[Category:Candidates for President of Iran]] [[Category:Combatant Clergy Association politicians]] [[Category:First Deputies of Islamic Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:Iranian businesspeople]] [[Category:Iranian clerics]] [[Category:Iranian democracy activists]] [[Category:Members of the 1st Islamic Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:Iranian prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Iranian revolutionaries]] [[Category:Islamic Republican Party politicians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the 2nd Islamic Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:Members of the 3rd Islamic Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:Members of the 6th Islamic Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:National Trust Party (Iran) politicians]] [[Category:People from Aligudarz]] [[Category:People of the Iranian Revolution]] [[Category:Second Deputies of Islamic Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:Speakers of the Islamic Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:Secretaries-General of political parties in Iran]] [[Category:People who have been placed under house arrest in Iran]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Mu Sigma Inc. | logo = Mu Sigma Logo.jpg | type = [[India]]n [[Privately Owned]] | founder = [[Dhiraj Rajaram]] | foundation = (2004){{cite web | title = Getting the numbers right |work = EMERGE Forum | publisher = [[NASSCOM]] | url = http://emerge.nasscom.in/2011/09/getting-the-numbers-right/ | date = September 27, 2011 | accessdate = Jun 18, 2012 }} | location = [[Bangalore]],
[[India]] | industry = [[Management consulting]] | services = [[Data analytics]] | num_employees = 3,500+ (2016) | homepage = {{url|http://www.mu-sigma.com}} }} '''Mu Sigma''' is an Indian [[management consulting]] firm that primarily offers [[data analytics]] services. The firm's name is derived from the statistical terms "Mu (μ)" and "Sigma (σ)" which symbolize the [[mean]] and the [[standard deviation]] respectively of a [[probability distribution]]. Mu Sigma is headquartered in [[Bengaluru]] and has a United States branch office in [[Chicago]]. == History == Mu Sigma was founded by [[Dhiraj Rajaram]], a former strategy consultant for the India branches of [[Booz Allen Hamilton]] and [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]], in 2004. In 2008, Mu Sigma raised its first institutional investment round of $30 million from FTVentures (now FTV Capital).{{cite web | title = FTVentures Commits $30 Million to Mu Sigma (press release) | date = September 24, 2008 | work = FTVentures | url = http://www.ftvcapital.com/newsletters/20081001.html | accessdate = June 18, 2012 }} In April 2011, the company raised an additional $25 million from [[Sequoia Capital]].{{cite news |date = June 6, 2011 | title = The Daily Start-Up: Sequoia Makes "Big Data" Move With Mu Sigma | work = Venture Capital Dispatch | publisher = [[Wall Street Journal]] | url = https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2011/06/06/the-daily-start-up-sequoia-makes-big-data-move-with-mu-sigma/ | accessdate = June 18, 2012 }} In December 2011, the company announced a $108 million round of financing from Sequoia and growth equity investor [[General Atlantic]].{{cite news | title = Mu Sigma Lands Big Money for Big Data |publisher = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203899504577126720815824762 | date = December 29, 2011 | accessdate = Nov 23, 2012 }} In February 2013, Mu Sigma received an investment of $45 million from [[MasterCard]], which placed the company over the $1 billion (Rs. 5,400 crore{{efn|At time of transaction}}) milestone.{{cite news| url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-02-20/news/37200522_1_dhiraj-rajaram-mu-sigma-data-analytics | work=The Times Of India | title=Mu Sigma attracts a clutch of foreign investors, gets valued at billion, Dhiraj Rajaram is now king of data analysis,data science and predictions by | date=February 20, 2013}} In early 2016, the company was sued by [[Aon (company)|Aon Corp]] founder [[Pat Ryan (executive)|Pat Ryan]], who discussed that Mu Sigma lowballed its own growth prospects in order to buy back Ryan's stake in the company. Ryan won the court case.{{cite news|last1=Mehrotra|first1=Kartikay|title=Aon founder Pat Ryan sues Mu Sigma, claims lowball buyout|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/bluesky/technology/ct-pat-ryan-mu-sigma-20160310-story.html|accessdate=21 December 2017|work=Chicago Tribune|date=10 March 2016}} In October 2016 Dhiraj Rajaram took over the role of CEO from his estranged wife, Ambiga Subramanian, who was currently serving as CEO at the time. The couple split in 2016, post which Dhiraj became the CEO.http://www.financialexpress.com/industry/unicorn-mu-sigma-founder-dhiraj-rajaram-takes-control-including-role-of-ceofrom-estranged-wife/406130/{{Cite news|url=https://inc42.com/buzz/mu-sigma-ambiga-subramanian-social-media-startup-hyphen-social/|title=Mu Sigma’s Ex-CEO Ambiga Subramanian To Roll Out Her Own Social Media Startup Hyphen.Social|date=2017-11-10|work=Inc42 Media|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}} ==Recognition== Mu Sigma was ranked #907 on the 2012 [[Inc. 5000]] list of America's fastest-growing private companies. In 2011 the company ranked #386, and in 2010, it ranked #204.{{cite web | title = Inc. 5000 Profile | date = September 2011 | work = [[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]] | url = http://www.inc.com/inc5000/profile/mu-sigma | accessdate = June 18, 2012 }} Rajaram, the company's founder and chairman, was ranked 37 on the [[Fortune Magazine]] [[40 under 40 (Fortune Magazine)|40 under 40]] list in 2013.{{cite news|title=40 Under 40 - 37. Dhiraj Rajaram|url=http://money.cnn.com/gallery/magazines/fortune/2013/09/19/40-under-40.fortune/41.html?iid=40Under13_fl_list|work=CNN Money|accessdate=11 October 2013|first1=Daniel|last1=Roberts|first2=Rupali|last2=Arora|first3=Katie|last3=Benner|first4=Ryan|last4=Bradley|first5=Scott|last5=Cendrowski|first6=Catherine|last6=Dunn|first7=Eli|last7=Epstein|first8=Erika|last8=Fry|first9=Stephen|last9=Gandel|first10=Craig|last10=Giammona|first11=Beth|last11=Kowitt|first12=Colleen|last12=Leahey|first13=Michal|last13=Lev-Ram|first14=Jp|last14=Mangalindan|first15=Tory|last15=Newmyer|first16=Pattie|last16=Sellers|first17=Anne|last17=Vandermey|first18=Matt|last18=Vella|date=September 19, 2013}} Rajaram won the [[Ernst & Young]] Entrepreneur Of The Year India Award 2012 in the services category.{{cite web | title = Presenting the winners of Ernst & Young Entrepreneur Of The Year India Award 2012 | date = Feb 21, 2013 | work = [[Ernst & Young]] | url = http://www.ey.com/IN/en/Newsroom/News-releases/PR_Presenting-the-winners-of-Ernst-Young-Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year-India-Award-2012 | accessdate = June 3, 2013 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.mu-sigma.com}} [[Category:Analytics]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Award |name=Onizuka Prop Wash Award |image=Onizuka Prop Wash Award Image.png |imagesize=200px |caption= |description=Contribution to class spirit |presenter=United States Air Force Test Pilot School Students |location=[[Edwards Air Force Base]] |country={{USA}} |year={{Start date|1956}} |website= }} The '''Onizuka Prop Wash Award''' recognizes the student at the [[U.S. Air Force Test Pilot School|United States Air Force Test Pilot School]] (USAF TPS) who contributed most to class spirit and [[morale]].{{cite web |last= Taylor |first=Annamaria |title = TPS class 09A graduates |url= http://www.edwards.af.mil/News/Article/395451/tps-class-09a-graduates/ |publisher=United States Air Force |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=April 29, 2017}} The honoree from each class is selected by his or her fellow students rather than by school faculty. The award is named in memory of TPS graduate [[Ellison Onizuka]] who perished in the explosion of the [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|Space Shuttle ''Challenger'']] in 1986.{{cite book |title = USAF Test Pilot School 50 Years and Beyond |publisher=Privately Published |year=1994 |page = 220}} ==History== The Prop Wash Award was introduced at the USAF Test Pilot school in 1956. The award takes the form of a wooden [[Propeller (aircraft)|aircraft propellor]] to which plaques bearing the name of each honoree are mounted. ''[[Prop wash#Spiral slipstream|Prop wash]]'' refers to the [[spiral]]-shaped slipstream formed behind a rotating propeller on an [[aircraft]]. The phrase, ''[[Illegitimi non carborundum]]'', a [[Dog Latin|mock-Latin]] [[aphorism]] meaning "Don't let the bastards grind you down" is engraved on the face. The first recipient of the award was Major Joseph W. Rogers from class 56D who would later set a world speed record in the [[Convair F-106 Delta Dart]].{{cite web |last=Young |first=James |title=Milestones in Aerospace History at Edwards AFB |url=http://www.af.mil/shared/media/document/afd-080123-063.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418203006/http://www.af.mil/shared/media/document/afd-080123-063.pdf |archive-date = April 18, 2009 |date=August 2007 |publisher=United States Air Force |accessdate=April 29, 2017}} Captain Onizuka was also a recipient when he graduated from the Test Pilot School with class 74B. After Onizuka's death, the members of his class requested a rededication of the award. The inscription was changed in June 1988 for the graduation of TPS class 87B. {{quote|There is a lot of Ell here always… I thank you all for giving Ell a permanent place here, because (Edwards) is so important in our lives.|Lorna Onizuka, 1990|{{cite book |title = USAF Test Pilot School 50 Years and Beyond |publisher=Privately Published |year=1994 |page = 221}}}} The USAF Test Pilot School participates in an [[exchange program]] with other test communities. [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] and [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine Corps]] students from the [[United States Naval Test Pilot School|Naval Test Pilot School]] at the [[Naval Air Station Patuxent River|Patuxent River Naval Air Station]], [[Maryland]] attend the USAF TPS and vice versa. Foreign students may also attend and include those from the [[Empire Test Pilots' School]] at [[Boscombe Down]], [[England]], and the [[EPNER]] (École du Personnel Navigant d'Essais et de Réception), the French Test Pilots' School.{{cite web | title = Graduate Course Catalog and Student Handbook, 2007–08 | publisher = USAF TPS Curriculum Standards Division | date = June 22, 2007 | url = http://www.edwards.af.mil/shared/media/document/AFD-071001-069.pdf |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080910045404/http://www.edwards.af.mil/shared/media/document/AFD-071001-069.pdf |archive-date = September 10, 2008 | page=18 | format = PDF | accessdate = April 29, 2017}} All students at the USAF TPS are eligible to receive the Prop Wash Award. ==Recipients== The following table contains an incomplete list of Onizuka Prop Wash award recipients including name, country (if not the United States of America), [[military branch]] (if not the United States Air Force), [[military rank]] at the time of the award, and USAF Test Pilot School class number. |date = December 2, 2008 |publisher = Aerofiles |location = Paradise, California |accessdate = January 8, 2012 }} [[Category:Aviation awards]]

In [[business]], '''operating margin'''—also known as '''operating income margin''', '''operating profit margin''', '''EBIT margin''' and '''return on sales''' ('''ROS''')—is the ratio of [[operating income]] ("operating profit" in the [[United Kingdom|UK]]) to [[Revenue|net sales]], usually presented in percent. : \mathrm{Operating\ margin} = \left ( \frac {\mathrm{Operating\ income}}{\mathrm{Revenue}} \right ). ''[[Net profit]]'' measures the [[Profit (accounting)|profitability]] of ventures after accounting for all costs.Farris, Paul W.; Neil T. Bendle; Phillip E. Pfeifer; David J. Reibstein (2010). ''Marketing Metrics: The Definitive Guide to Measuring Marketing Performance.'' Upper Saddle River, New Jersey: Pearson Education, Inc. {{ISBN|0137058292}}. The [[Marketing Accountability Standards Board (MASB)]] endorses the definitions, purposes, and constructs of classes of measures that appear in ''Marketing Metrics'' as part of its ongoing [http://www.themasb.org/common-language-project/ Common Language: Marketing Activities and Metrics Project] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212100753/http://www.themasb.org/common-language-project/ |date=2013-02-12 }}. ''Return on sales (ROS)'' is net profit as a percentage of sales [[revenue]]. ROS is an indicator of profitability and is often used to compare the profitability of companies and industries of differing sizes. Significantly, ROS does not account for the [[Capital (economics)|capital]] ([[investment]]) used to generate the profit. In a survey of nearly 200 senior marketing managers, 69 percent responded that they found the "return on sales" metric very useful. Unlike [[EBITDA|Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA)]] margin, operating margin takes into account depreciation and amortization expenses. ==Purpose== These financial metrics measure levels and rates of [[Profit (accounting)|profitability]]. How does a company decide whether it is successful or not? Probably the most common way is to look at the [[net profit]]s of the business. Companies are collections of projects and markets, individual areas can be judged on how successful they are at adding to the corporate net profit. Not all projects are of equal size, however, and one way to adjust for size is to divide the profit by sales [[revenue]]. The resulting ratio is return on sales (ROS), the percentage of sales revenue that gets 'returned' to the company as net profits after all the related costs of the activity are deducted. ==Construction== Net profit measures the fundamental profitability of the business. It is the revenues of the activity less the costs of the activity. The main complication is in more complex businesses when overhead needs to be allocated across divisions of the company. . . . Almost by definition, overheads are costs that cannot be directly tied to any specific product or division. The classic example would be the cost of headquarters staff. '''''Net''' '''profit''': To calculate net profit for a unit (such as a company or division), subtract all costs, including a fair share of total corporate overheads, from the gross revenues. :Net profit ($) = Sales revenue ($) − Total costs ($) '''''Return on sales (ROS):''' Net profit as a percentage of sales revenue''. :Return on sales (%) = Net profit ($) / Sales revenue ($) [[EBITDA|Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization (EBITDA)]] is a very popular measure of financial performance. It is used to assess the 'operating' profit of the business. It is a rough way of calculating how much cash the business is generating and is even sometimes called the 'operating cash flow'. It can be useful because it removes factors that change the view of performance depending upon the accounting and financing policies of the business. Supporters argue it reduces management's ability to change the profits they report by their choice of accounting rules and the way they generate financial backing for the company. This metric excludes from consideration expenses related to decisions such as how to finance the business (debt or equity) and over what period they depreciate fixed assets. EBITDA is typically closer to actual cash flow than is [[NOPAT]]. ... EBITDA can be calculated by adding back the costs of interest, depreciation, and amortization charges and any taxes incurred. EBITDA ($) = Net profit ($) + Interest Payments ($) + Taxes Incurred ($) + Depreciation and Amortization Charges ($) '''Example: The Coca-Cola Company'''The Coca Cola Company Form 10-K SEC Filing 2006, p 67 {| cellpadding="3" width="350" |+ '''Consolidated Statements of Income'''
(In millions) |- | ''Net Operating Revenues'' | ''$ 20,088'' |- | [[Gross Profit]] | $15,924 |- | ''[[Operating Income]]'' | ''$ 6,318'' |- | Income Before Income Taxes | $6,578 |- | [[Net Income]] | $5,080 |} (Relevant figures in italics) \mathrm{Operating\ margin} = \left ( \frac {6,318}{20,088} \right ) = \underline{\underline{31.45 \%}} It is a measurement of what proportion of a company's revenue is left over, before taxes and other indirect costs (such as rent, bonus, interest, ''etc''.), after paying for variable costs of production as wages, raw materials, ''etc''. A good operating margin is needed for a company to be able to pay for its fixed costs, such as interest on debt. A higher operating margin means that the company has less financial risk. Operating margin can be considered total revenue from product sales less all costs before adjustment for taxes, dividends to shareholders, and interest on debt. ==See also== *[[Efficiency ratio]] *[[Incremental operating margin]] *[[Profit margin]] ==References== * Farris, Paul W.; Neil T. Bendle; Phillip E. Pfeifer; David J. Reibstein (2010). ''Marketing Metrics: The Definitive Guide to Measuring Marketing Performance.'' [[Category:Financial ratios]] [[Category:Management accounting]] [[Category:Pricing]]
